description: Petitioner appeals the court of appealsâ€™ dismissal of the petitionerâ€™s appeal as untimely.  Petitioner also appeals the family courtâ€™s award of child support and denial of attorneyâ€™s fees.  We affirm in part and reverse in part.

  THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Michael E. Upchurch,  Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Susan O. Upchurch, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Colleton County
Â Jane D. Fender, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 26090
Heard September 21, 2005 - Filed January 3, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART 


  
    
      
        Gregory Samuel Forman, of Charleston, for Petitioner.
        Lucius Scott Harvin, of Hetrick Law Firm, of Walterboro, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  We granted certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™ dismissal of Susan Upchurchâ€™s appeal of a family court order as untimely. Â Upchurch v. Upchurch, 359 S.C. 254, 597 S.E.2d 819 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We also review the family courtâ€™s award of child support and denial of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
Factual / Procedural Background
Michael E. Upchurch (â€œHusbandâ€) and Susan O. Upchurch (â€œWifeâ€) were married in March of 1981.Â  The parties had three children together.Â  They were divorced in February of 2001.Â  
The parties entered into a separation agreement, which was incorporated into the final divorce decree.Â  The divorce decree granted joint custody to the parties, with Husband designated as the primary custodial parent.Â  At the time of the divorce, the family court relied on the incorporated separation agreement in determining the need for child support. Â The separation agreement provided that â€œ[d]ue to the current financial situation of the parties, including wifeâ€™s establishment of a new household in Charleston, South Carolina, the husband waives child support.Â  The husband and wife may decide to revisit the issue of child support should the financial situation of either party change dramatically.â€ On September 26, 2001, Husband brought a petition requesting that Wife pay private school tuition and child support for their minor children.Â  Wife counterclaimed for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
At the hearing, Husband testified about changed circumstances including his oldest daughterâ€™s college expenses, increased medical costs uncovered by insurance, and orthodontic treatment for all three children.Â  Wife objected only to the relevance of testimony regarding the college expenses of the oldest child, these expenses having occurred beyond the daughterâ€™s eighteenth birthday.Â Â  
The family court denied Husbandâ€™s claim for private school tuition, but granted his petition for child support in accordance with the statutory guidelines, retroactive to the filing of the petition.Â  The family court denied Wifeâ€™s counterclaim for attorneyâ€™s fees.
The family court order was signed on May 30, 2002.Â  The following day, the courtâ€™s administrative assistant mailed the original signed order to the clerk of court with a letter requesting that the clerk file the order and send certified copies to the attorneys of record.Â  This letter, including copies of the signed order, was carbon copied to both attorneys of record.Â  The order was not filed until June 12, 2002.Â  Wife did not receive service of the filed order until August 23, 2002, and on September 11, 2002, Wife appealed.Â  
The court of appeals dismissed the action as untimely. Â This Court granted certiorari to review the following issues:

  
    I. 
    Did the court of appeals err in dismissing Wife’s appeal as untimely?
  
  
    II. 
    Did the family court err in awarding child support without a showing of a dramatically changed financial situation or changed circumstances?
  
  
    III.
    Did the family court err in allowing the presentation of evidence regarding changed circumstances? 
  
  
    IV.
    Did the family court err in awarding retroactive child support?
  
  
    V.
    Did the family court err in denying Wife’s claim for attorney’s fees?
  

Law / Analysis
I.  Timing of the Appeal
Wife argues that the court of appeals erred in dismissing her appeal as untimely.Â  We agree.
Our Court rules provide that â€œ[a] notice of appeal shall be served on all respondents within thirty (30) days after receipt of written notice of entry of the order or judgment.â€Â  Rule 203(b), SCACR (emphasis added).Â  Generally, a judgment is effective only when so set forth and entered in the record.Â  Rule 58(a) SCRCP.Â  An order is not final until it is entered by the clerk of court; and until the order or judgment is entered by the clerk of the court, the judge retains control of the case.Â  Bowman v. Richland Memâ€™l Hosp., 335 S.C. 88, 91, 515 S.E.2d 259, 260 (Ct. App. 1999) (citations omitted).Â  However, â€œthe moment â€¦[the order] is filed by the clerk of court, it becomes the judgment of the court, and fixes the rights of the parties.â€Â  Archer v. Long, 46 S.C. 292, 295, 24 S.E. 83, 84 (1896).Â  Stated otherwise, the effective date of an order is not when it is signed by the judge, but when it is entered by the clerk of court.Â  Bowman, 335 S.C. at 93, 515 S.E.2d at 261.Â  
Two court of appeals cases offer further analysis as to when notice occurs under our procedural rules.
In Bowman v. Richland Memâ€™l Hosp., the trial court dismissed the respondent as a party based on the appellantsâ€™ failure to amend the complaint within ten (10) days of the date of the trial courtâ€™s order.Â  Id at 90, 515 S.E.2d at 259.Â  The order was signed on September 19, 1996, but was not entered by the clerk until September 23, 1996.Â  The appellants served an amended complaint on October 2, 1996, which was 13 days after the order was signed and 9 days after the order was filed.Â  The court of appeals held that the appellantâ€™s amendment of the complaint was timely, finding that the â€œfinal and effective date of the trial judgeâ€™s order was the date the order was entered by the clerk of courtâ€¦, not when the order was signed.â€Â  Id at 92, 515 S.E.2d at 261.Â  
In Rosen, Rosen & Hagood v. Hiller, the court of appeals addressed the notice requirement under Rule 12(a), SCRCP. [1]Â  307 S.C. 331, 415 S.E.2d 117 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  The appellant in the Rosen case made a motion to the trial court for a change of venue.Â  The motion was denied after the appellant failed to appear at the hearing.Â  The respondentâ€™s attorney mailed a letter to the appellant which included an unsigned, undated, and unfiled copy of the order issued by the court denying appellantâ€™s motion.Â  The respondent subsequently moved for an order of default because the appellant did not file an answer as required by Rule 12(a), SCRCP.Â  Â The appellant argued that he had not received notice of the courtâ€™s action because he had not received the signed, dated, and filed order as required by Rule 77(d), SCRCP.[2]Â  The court of appeals rejected this argument, stating â€œwe see nothing in Rule 12(a) that requires the actual filed order be served upon a party to affect notice [of the courtâ€™s action].â€Â  Id at 334, 415 S.E.2d at 118.
Because a critical issue of this case is entry of the order of judgment, we find the instant case more comparable with Bowman.Â  In Bowman, the court held that principles of fairness and equity required a finding of timeliness because â€œparties to an action are not provided notice of a judgeâ€™s ruling at the time the judge signs an order.Â  Rather, only after the order is filed with the clerk of court are the parties given notice of the order.â€Â  Bowman, 335 S.C. at 92, 515 S.E.2d at 261.Â  To hold Wife responsible for notice of an event that had not yet occurred runs afoul of the notions of fairness and equity articulated in Bowman.Â  
By its plain language, Rule 203(b) requires notice of entry of the order.Â  Entry of the order occurs when the clerk of court files the order.Â  Delivery of the order to the clerk is not analogous to the entry of the order.Â  Accordingly, we hold that the time to file a notice of appeal pursuant to Rule 203(b), SCACR, begins to run when written notice that the order has been entered into the record by the clerk of court has been received.Â  Therefore, the May 31st letter from the judgeâ€™s assistant was not notice of entry of judgment; the very language of the letter indicated that the order had not yet been filed.Â  Accordingly, the court of appeals erred in dismissing the appeal as untimely. 
II.  Child Support
Wife contends that the family court erred in awarding child support without a showing of dramatically changed financial situation or changed circumstances.Â  We agree.
In order to determine the proper standard, we must first determine if this is 1) an action to establish an order of child support or 2) an action to modify an order of child support.Â  
Generally, a petition is treated as an action to establish child support if the issue was not addressed previously in the separation agreement or the divorce decree.Â  McElrath v. Walker, 285 S.C. 439, 440, 330 S.E.2d 313, 313 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  However, when the divorce decree or separation agreement addresses the issue of child support, the petition is considered one for modification. Miller v. Miller, 299 S.C. 307, 310-11, 384 S.E.2d 715, 716-17 (1989) (reviewing the denial of a petition to decrease child support set by the divorce decree using the modification standard of changed circumstances). Â Additionally, it is possible for the issue of child support to be held in abeyance by the divorce decree or incorporated separation agreement.Â  Boyer v. Boyer 291 S.C. 183, 184-85, 352 S.E.2d 514, 515-16 (Ct. App. 1987) (holding that the court could award child support without a showing of changed circumstances where the original divorce decree awarded child support to be set after a specified time upon petition to the court). Â Â Nevertheless, an agreement between the parents may not affect the basic support rights of minor children.Â  Lunsford v. Lunsford, 277 S.C. 104, 105, 282 S.E.2d 861, 862 (1981).Â  Notwithstanding any provisions of a separation agreement, the family court retains jurisdiction to do whatever is in the best interest of the children.Â  Moseley v. Mosier, 279 S.C. 348, 351, 306 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1983).Â Â Â Â  
We hold that the petition in the instant case was one for modification of child support.Â  The separation agreement, which was incorporated into the divorce decree, specifically addresses the issue of child support.Â  Furthermore, there is no indication in the separation agreement or the divorce decree that the issue of child support would be held in abeyance.Â  Therefore, any subsequent review of the issue by the family court would be for modification.Â  
The separation agreement, in the instant case, provided that the parties may â€œrevisit the issue of child support should the financial situation of either party change dramatically.â€Â  This language essentially mirrors the courtâ€™s own changed circumstances standard for modification of child support obligations.Â  Therefore, the courtâ€™s application of the changed circumstances standard encompasses the standard agreed on by the parties. Accordingly, we do not need to determine if parties may change the standard for modification of a child support award by agreement.Â  Therefore, applying the standard of changed circumstances, we find that Husband did not provide sufficient evidence to warrant a modification of the original decree. 
A child support award rests in the discretion of the trial judge, and will not be altered on appeal absent abuse of discretion.Â  Hallums v. Hallums, 296 S.C. 195, 197, 371 S.E.2d 525, 527 (1988).Â  However, in reviewing an appeal from the family court, the appellate court may find the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).
The family court may always modify child support upon a proper showing of a change in either the childâ€™s needs or the supporting parentâ€™s financial ability.Â  Moseley, 279 S.C. at 351, 306 S.E.2d at 626.Â Â  The party seeking the modification has the burden to show changed circumstances.Â  Miller, 299 S.C. at 310, 384 S.E.2d at 716. Â This burden is increased where the child support award is based on a settlement agreement.Â  Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 70, 74, 587 S.E.2d 118, 120 (Ct. App. 2003). However, changes within the contemplation of the parties at the time of the initial decree are not sufficient bases for the modification of a child support award.Â  Miller, 299 S.C. at 310, 384 S.E.2d at 717.Â  Further, general testimony regarding increased expenses, without specific evidentiary support, is an insufficient showing of changed circumstances.Â  Thornton v. Thornton, 294 S.C. 512, 516, 366 S.E.2d 37, 39 (Ct. App. 1988).
Husband testified generally about changed circumstances, but provided few concrete figures to support his claim.Â  Husband also relied on expenses such as orthodontic bills and private school tuition which were likely anticipated at the time of the separation agreement and divorce decree.[3]Â  This testimony alone does not provide sufficient proof of a change in the childrenâ€™s needs or circumstances to modify the previous child support order. 
Additionally, Wife did not submit a financial declaration in the initial divorce proceeding.Â  Therefore, in the present case, the family court faced further challenges in determining if Wifeâ€™s current financial situation differed from her situation at the time of the divorce.Â  Evidence was presented to show that Wife no longer had a house in Charleston as outlined in the divorce decree, but no further evidence of changed circumstances appears in the record.Â  
Accordingly, this Court finds that Husband failed to prove changed circumstances and the record is insufficient to justify the modification of the child support award.Â  Therefore, the family courtâ€™s order awarding child support to Husband is reversed.Â Â  
III.  Evidence of Changed Circumstances
Wife asserts that the family court erred in allowing the presentation of evidence regarding changed circumstances not pled in the Husbandâ€™s complaint.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œWhen issues not raised by the pleadings are tried by express or implied consent of the parties, they shall be treated in all respects as if they had been raised in the pleadings.â€Â  Rule 15(b), SCRCP; McCurry v. Keith, 325 S.C. 441 ,447, 481 S.E.2d 166, 169 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  If a party does not object to the evidence when presented at trial, the issue is considered tried by consent.Â  Simmons v. Tuomey Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 330 S.C. 115, 120 n.2, 498 S.E.2d Â 408, 410 n.2 (Ct. App. 1998).
Wife consented to the presentation of the evidence regarding changed circumstances because she only objected to the testimony regarding college expenses for the oldest child.Â  Wife did not object to any other testimony presented at trial.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the family courtâ€™s admission of testimony regarding changed circumstances.
IV. Retroactive Child Support
Wife contends that the family court erred in awarding child support retroactive to the filing of the petition for support.Â  We agree.
The award of retroactive child support is incident to the award of general child support.Â  Because we reverse the family courtâ€™s award of child support, the award of retroactive child support does not need to be addressed.Â  
V.  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Wife contends that the family court erred in denying her claim for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(38) (Supp. 2004) authorizes the family court to award attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The award of attorneyâ€™s fees is left to the discretion of the trial judge and will only be disturbed upon a showing of abuse of discretion.Â  Ariail v. Ariail, 295 S.C. 486, 489, 369 S.E.2d 146, 148 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  In making this determination, the court should evaluate the requesting partyâ€™s ability to pay, the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, the effect of the award on each partyâ€™s standard of living, and the beneficial results achieved.Â  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004).Â  Beneficial result alone is not dispositive of whether a party is entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Mazzone v. Miles, 341 S.C. 203,214, 532 S.E.2d 890, 894 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
The family court did not make any specific findings as to the reasons for denial of the request for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Further, in light of the evidence in the record, we cannot conclude that either party is in a position to pay the otherâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not abuse its discretion in denying Wifeâ€™s claim for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
Conclusion
Based on the above reasoning, we reverse the court of appealsâ€™ decision dismissing Wifeâ€™s appeal as untimely.Â  We also reverse the family courtâ€™s modification of child support and the award of retroactive child support.Â  Finally, we affirm the admission of testimony regarding changed circumstances and the denial of wifeâ€™s claim for attorneyâ€™s fees.
MOORE, WALLER, and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurring in result only.

[1] Rule 12(a), SCRCP, provides that â€œif the Court denies the motion or postpones its disposition until the trial on the merits, the responsive pleading shall be served within 15 days after notice of the Court's actionâ€¦â€ (emphasis added).
[2] Rule 77(d), SCRCP states that â€œimmediately upon the entry of an order or judgment the clerk shall serve a notice of the entry by first class mail upon every party affected thereby who is not in default for failure to appear, and shall make a note in the case file or docket sheet of the mailing. Such mailing shall not be necessary to parties who have already received notice. Such mailing is sufficient notice for all purposes for which notice of the entry of an order or judgment is required by these rules; but any party may in addition serve a notice of entry on any other party in the manner provided in Rule 5 for the service of such papers.â€ 
[3] Husband filed the petition for child support just eight months after the order of divorce.Â

description: In this PCR case, the Court finds counsel was not ineffective for failing to object to the solicitor's mention of a polygraph in closing argument.

Ellenburg v. St


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Stephen Ray Ellenburg, Respondent,
v.
State of South Carolina,
Petitioner,
      
    
  


Appeal from Oconee County
J. Cordell Maddox, Circuit Court Judge

ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Opinion No. 26091
Submitted November 16, 2005 - Filed January 9, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Christopher L. Newton, all of Columbia, for petitioner.
Tara Dawn Shurling, of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  This case is before us on a writ of certiorari to review the lower courtâ€™s order granting post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Respondent was convicted of safecracking, second degree burglary, and petit larceny for robbing a Subway Sandwich Shop where he was formerly employed.Â  The robbery occurred on April 29, 1997, after the store closed and the last employee had left at 1:15 a.m.Â  The store alarm set automatically at 2:00 a.m. and there was no sign of a break-in.Â  The cash register indicated that it had been opened at 1:44 a.m.Â  More than $400 was taken from the cash register, another $250 was taken from a file cabinet, and the dial on the storeâ€™s safe was destroyed.Â  
The store manager testified that all employees knew the code for the cash register, and employees who worked the closing shift, including respondent, knew the alarm set automatically at 2:00 a.m.
The only evidence linking respondent to the crime was the testimony of Jeremy Littleton.Â  Littleton testified he planned the robbery with respondent and another man.Â  Littleton, who was an employee at the time and had a key, unlocked the back door and waited while the other two went in and robbed the store.Â  The three of them split the money.
During direct examination by the solicitor, Littleton testified as follows:

  
    
      
        Q:  
         Okay.Â  How did you come about to get arrested?
           
      
      
        A:
         I was sent to go do a polygraph test for everyone who had a key, and I gave Sergeant Moss my oral statement about what had went on and how I was involved.
           
      
      
        Q: 
         How did you feel about -----
           
      
      
        A: 
         I knew it was wrong.Â  I felt my conscience had made me do what I had done.Â  It made me come out and tell them what I had done.
      
    
  

Counsel moved for a mistrial based on Littletonâ€™s reference to a polygraph.Â  The motion was denied. 
In closing, counsel attempted to undermine Littletonâ€™s testimony:

But what did Jeremy testify to?Â  He said, Yes.Â  When I first went up to the law enforcement folks I denied that I was involved, and then the reason that he changed his story, they were getting ready to put him on a lie detector.Â  So he changes his story and says he was involved and doesnâ€™t have to take a lie detector. . . .
Heâ€™s getting ready to go see Sergeant Moss, and heâ€™s been denying that heâ€™s been involved in this crime.Â  Then theyâ€™re getting ready to put him on a lie detector, and what does he do?Â  He says, Let me tell you what happened.Â  Does he tell them the truth?Â  No.Â  He doesnâ€™t tell them the truth.Â  He gives them partial truth.Â  He admits part of it, but what doesnâ€™t he do?Â  He never puts himself inside the building.

In response, the solicitor argued:

Why would he (Jeremy Littleton) lie?Â  How was he being helped by making up this story?Â  He has no deal with me.Â  He is charged with the exact same crimes as the other two defendants.Â  He came up here, got on this stand, swore on the Bible, put his hands behind his back and stuck his chin out, and said, Solicitor, take your best shot at me. . . . Never mind that he had no deal with me, ladies and gentlemen, he had no deal with [Sergeant] Moss when he went in and talked to him.Â  When he came in, knowing that he was going to be put on the polygraph and confess because he knew that polygraph would catch him lying.

After respondentâ€™s conviction was affirmed on appeal, he commenced this PCR action.Â  The PCR judge found counsel was ineffective for failing to object to the solicitorâ€™s closing argument regarding the polygraph. 
ISSUE

Was counsel ineffective for failing to object to the solicitorâ€™s closing? 

DISCUSSION
First, the mere mention of a polygraph during testimony is not prejudicial where, as here, no results are introduced into evidence.Â  Bruno v. State, 347 S.C. 446, 556 S.E.2d 393 (2001).Â  Further, counsel testified he mentioned the polygraph during closing to give the jury an explanation that would exonerate his client i.e., Littleton told a â€œpartial truthâ€ to avoid having to take a polygraph, which would have revealed that he committed the robbery himself.Â  Counselâ€™s strategy was a reasonable way to cast doubt on Littletonâ€™s testimony implicating respondent.Â  Stokes v. State, 308 S.C. 546, 419 S.E.2d 778 (1992) (where counsel articulates valid reasons for employing certain strategy, such conduct will not be deemed ineffective assistance of counsel).Â Â  
We find the solicitorâ€™s argument was in fair response to counselâ€™s argument regarding the polygraph.Â  Once the defendant opens the door, the solicitorâ€™s invited response is appropriate so long as it is does not unfairly prejudice the defendant.Â  Cf. Vaughn v. State, 362 S.C. 163, 607 S.E.2d 72 (2004) (solicitorâ€™s comments not proper under invited response doctrine where there was no evidence to support them).Â  Since the evidence was that Littleton did not actually take the polygraph, it was arguable that either he told only a partial truth, as counsel argued, or he told the whole truth, implicating respondent as the solicitor argued.Â  Accordingly, the solicitorâ€™s argument was not unfair and counsel was not ineffective for failing to object.
CONCLUSION
Since the PCR judgeâ€™s ruling finding counsel ineffective is not supported by the evidence, the order granting relief Â is reversed.Â  See Bright v. State, 365 S.C. 355, 618 S.E.2d 296 (2005) (grant of PCR reversed where not supported by the record).
 REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â  WALLER, J., not participating.

title: Morris v. Monceaux
description: Appellant, the temporary custodian of a minor child, appealed the family courtâ€™s decision to issue a permanency planning order without holding an evidentiary hearing.  The Supreme Court held that it is error, in the face of a request by a party for an evidentiary hearing, for the family court to issue a permanency planning order based on an examination of the file and pleadings, the arguments of counsel, and the GALâ€™s report, but without considering testimony and evidence at a hearing where witnesses are subject to direct and cross-examination.  Although the Supreme Court found error, it affirmed the order of the family court because Appellant failed to appeal the ruling which dismissed her from the case.  In a related issue, the Supreme Court explained that a nonrelative such as Appellant who has a real, material, or substantial interest in the long-term custody and potential adoption of a child has standing to participate in a family court proceeding addressing those issues.

BENCH MEMORANDUM


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Ex parte: Â Amelia Beth Morris, Appellant.
In Re: Â South Carolina Department of Social Services,
Respondent,
v.
Paula Lynn Monceaux and John Doe, whose true identity is unknown,Â Defendants.
In the Interest of Trae Steven Monceaux, a minor under the age of eighteen years.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â Frances P. Segars-Andrews, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 26092
Submitted December 1, 2005 - Filed January 9, 2006

AFFIRMED IN RESULT


  
    
      
John S. Wilkerson, III, and Patrick W. Carr, both of Turner, Padget, Graham, and Laney, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Thomas P. Stoney, of the South Carolina Department of Social Services, Berkeley County, for Respondent.
Wolfgang L. Kelly, of Summerville, for the guardian ad litem for Trae Steven
Monceaux.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  This appeal raises the issue of whether the family court judge erred in a child custody case by issuing a permanency planning order without allowing the presentation of testimony and evidence at a hearing.Â  We affirm in result.
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Trae Steven Monceaux (Child) was born in 2001 and abandoned by his mother, who left him with a friend, Amelia Beth Morris (Custodian).Â  The motherâ€™s present whereabouts and the fatherâ€™s identity are unknown.Â  Custodian is not related by blood or marriage to Child.Â  Custodian apparently filed an action at an unspecified time to adopt Child, but did not pursue the action. 
The state Department of Social Services in Berkeley County (DSS) took Child into emergency protective custody in May 2003 pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-610 (Supp. 2004). Â DSS in a removal complaint filed pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-736 (Supp. 2004) alleged that Child, then two years old, was harmed or threatened with harm because Custodian physically neglected him.Â  A family court judge ruled probable cause existed to remove Child from the home and ordered DSS retain custody of Child.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-610(M) (Supp. 2004).
A two-day hearing on the merits of the removal action was held in July 2003.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-736(E) (Supp. 2004). Â A family court judge ruled that â€œremoval is justified in this case based upon a threat of physical harm to the child because of the instability of the home maintained by [Custodian],â€ and ordered DSS continue to retain custody of Child (emphasis in original).Â  The judge further ordered a treatment and placement plan pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-762 (Supp. 2004) in which Custodian was required to undergo assessments for mental health, anger management, alcohol and drug use, and financial matters, and follow all recommendations for counseling.Â  Custodian was required to take a parenting skills course, and maintain a safe and stable home and suitable employment.Â  
An initial permanency planning hearing was held in May 2004 pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-766 (Supp. 2004).Â  DSSâ€™s attorney explained the status and history of the case to the court, repeating the allegations of physical neglect and describing testimony and evidence presented at the removal hearing.Â  DSSâ€™s attorney briefly described alleged evidence in the case, including Custodianâ€™s purported use of illegal drugs and noncompliance with the treatment and placement plan, and Childâ€™s current placement with foster parents who wish to adopt him.Â  DSSâ€™s attorney asked the court to dismiss Custodian from the case and allow an action to terminate the rights of Childâ€™s parents to proceed so that Child may be adopted.
The DSS case managerâ€™s affidavit and written case evaluation supporting the agencyâ€™s position apparently were submitted to the court.Â  A report from the area Childrenâ€™s Foster Care Review Board which supported DSSâ€™s conclusions and recommendations apparently was submitted to the court.[1]  
Custodianâ€™s attorney stated that Custodian contested DSSâ€™s position and requested an evidentiary hearing to respond to the agencyâ€™s inaccurate and distorted description of her case. Â Custodianâ€™s attorney briefly described facts and evidence supporting Custodianâ€™s effort to regain custody of Child, including the fact she had recently begun complying with the treatment and placement plan, and had obtained an apartment and stable job.
Counsel for the GAL told the judge the GAL concurred with DSSâ€™s position and recommendations, and briefly described facts and evidence supporting DSSâ€™s position.
No party or witnesses offered live, sworn testimony at the hearing.Â  After listening to the attorneysâ€™ presentations, the family court judge rejected Custodianâ€™s request for an evidentiary hearing and ruled from the bench in favor of DSS.Â  The judge in a subsequent written order ruled Custodian lacked standing to participate in the case because she had failed to comply with the treatment and placement plan, and dismissed her from the case.Â  The judge directed DSS to initiate an action for termination of the rights of Childâ€™s parents so that he may be adopted. 
Custodian appealed.Â  We certified this case from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.
ISSUE

Did the family court judge err in basing her decision in a permanency planning order on the arguments of counsel, the GALâ€™s report, and an examination of the case file and pleadings, but without considering testimony and evidence at a hearing where witnesses are subject to direct and cross-examination?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, the appellate court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its view of the preponderance of the evidence. 
Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad scope of review does not, however, require the appellate court to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981). Â This degree of deference is especially true in cases involving the welfare and best interests of a minor child.Â  Latimer v. Farmer, 360 S.C. 375, 380, 602 S.E.2d 32, 34 (2004); Dixon v. Dixon, 336 S.C. 260, 263, 519 S.E.2d 357, 359 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Moreover, the appellate courtâ€™s broad scope of review does not relieve the appellant of the burden of showing that the family court committed error.Â  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 523, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979).
LAW AND ANALYSIS
As an initial matter, we take this opportunity to clarify the issue of Custodianâ€™s standing in this matter.Â  The family court judge ruled Custodian had no standing to participate in the proceeding because she had failed to rehabilitate herself and complete the treatment and placement plan.Â  DSS in its brief repeatedly mentions that Custodian is not related to Child by blood or marriage, as if that fact alone somehow negates any standing or right to appear before the family court and assert which plan is best for Child.
As a general rule, to have standing, a litigant must have a personal stake in the subject matter of the litigation.Â  Glaze v. Grooms, 324 S.C. 249, 255, 478 S.E.2d 841, 845 (1996).Â  One must be a real party in interest, i.e., a party who has a real, material, or substantial interest in the subject matter of the action, as opposed to one who has only a nominal or technical interest in the action.Â  Id.; Charleston County School Dist. v. Charleston County Elec. Commn., 336 S.C. 174, 181, 519 S.E.2d 567, 571 (1999).Â  
While Custodian may not stand on precisely the same footing as a parent or close relative, it is apparent from a reading of various statutes touching on the issue that the Legislature contemplated nonrelatives often may play a crucial and important role in the life and well-being of a child, particularly when parents or relatives turn away from the child.Â  See e.g. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-490(3) (Supp. 2004) (defining â€œa person responsible for a childâ€™s welfareâ€ to include a parent, guardian, foster parent, caregiver, â€œor an adult who has assumed the role or responsibility of a parent or guardian for the child, but who does not necessarily have legal custody of the childâ€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-766(G) (Supp. 2004) (family court at the permanency planning stage for a child removed from his home may award custody or legal guardianship to a â€œsuitable, fit, and willing relative or nonrelativeâ€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-766(K) (Supp. 2004) (â€œAny other party in interest may move to intervene in the case pursuant to the rules of civil procedure and if the motion is granted, may move for review.Â  Parties in interest include, but are not limited to, the individual or agency with legal custody or placement of the child and the foster parent.â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-610 (Supp. 2004) (emergency protective custody statute which repeatedly uses the terms â€œother personâ€ or â€œcustodianâ€ in addition to â€œparentâ€ or â€œguardianâ€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-435 (1985) (listing â€œcustodianâ€ among persons who may institute proceedings regarding a neglected or delinquent child); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-480 (Supp. 2004) (expressing legislative philosophy that, while parents have primary responsibility for their children, the welfare of neglected or abused children is a concern of the entire community); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-50 and -70 (Supp. 2004) (establishing criminal penalties for any person who â€œhas charge or custody of a childâ€ or who â€œis responsible for the welfare of a childâ€ and is convicted of committing certain unlawful conduct towards a child).Â  
A nonrelative such as Custodian who has a real, material, or substantial interest in the long-term custody and potential adoption of a child has standing to participate in a family court proceeding addressing those issues.Â  Accordingly, we reject the notion Custodian somehow lacks standing to appear in this case or argue on behalf of Child simply because she is not related to Child by blood or marriage, or because she failed to comply with a treatment and placement plan.[2]Â  
Turning to the issue of an evidentiary hearing, Custodian argues the family court is required by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-766(C) (Supp. 2004) to find compelling reasons for approval of a permanency plan which does not involve reunification of the child with the parent or custody or guardianship with a fit and willing relative.Â  Custodian contends an appropriate decision in the important matters of long-term custody and potential adoption may not be reached when the family court considers only the arguments of counsel and a GALâ€™s report, but refuses to consider testimony and evidence at a hearing where parties and witnesses are subject to direct and cross-examination.Â  We agree.
It is error, in the face of a request by a party for an evidentiary hearing, for the family court to issue a permanency planning order based on an examination of the file and pleadings, the arguments of counsel, and the GALâ€™s report, but without considering testimony and evidence at a hearing where witnesses are subject to direct and cross-examination.
It is well established that counselâ€™s statements regarding the facts of a case and counselâ€™s arguments are not admissible evidence.Â  E.g. McManus v. Bank of Greenwood, 171 S.C. 84, 89, 171 S.E. 473, 475 (1933) (appellate courts repeatedly have held â€œthat statements of fact appearing only in arguments of counsel will not be consideredâ€); S.C. Dept. of Transp. v. Thompson, 357 S.C. 101, 105, 590 S.E.2d 511, 513 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œ[a]rguments made by counsel are not evidenceâ€).Â  Consequently, the family court may not base necessary findings of fact and conclusions of law solely on counselâ€™s statements of fact or arguments.Â  See Section 20-7-766(A) (requiring family court to make specific findings in a permanency planning order). Â 
In addition, written affidavits and reports generally constitute inadmissible hearsay, with some exceptions, although they may become admissible in whole or part when a proper foundation is laid by a witnessâ€™s testimony.Â  See Rules 801-804, SCRE; Rule 7, SCRFC.Â  The family court properly may review and rely on previous orders and pleadings contained in a particular case in resolving the issues at hand, but should not rely solely on these documents in issuing a permanency planning order.
Finally, and perhaps most importantly, it is apparent from a plain reading of Section 20-7-766 that the Legislature intended the family court hold an evidentiary hearing before issuing a permanency planning order when a hearing is necessitated by the facts of a case, the material facts are contested by the parties, or a hearing is requested by a party.Â  The Legislature repeatedly used the term â€œhearingâ€ throughout the statute, indicating a proceeding at which parties are allowed to present evidence and sworn testimony bearing on issues before the family court.Â  Furthermore, the permanency planning process set forth in Section 20-7-766 and related statutes involves the long-term custody of a child, the potential termination of parental rights, and the possible adoption of the child in the future.Â  Decisions regarding matters of such import must be made after careful, deliberate consideration of admissible evidence and sworn testimony presented by interested parties and witnesses at an evidentiary hearing.
Although the family court judge erred in rejecting Custodianâ€™s request for an evidentiary hearing, we affirm the result in this case.Â  The family court judge ordered, among other things, that Custodian â€œis dismissed as a party to this action.â€Â  Custodian has appealed only the issue of whether an evidentiary hearing was required, not her dismissal from the case.Â  This unappealed ruling is the law of the case and requires affirmance.Â  See e.g. Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 338 S.C. 171, 175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) (unappealed ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case and requires affirmance); Buckner v. Preferred Mut. Ins. Co., 255 S.C. 159, 177 S.E.2d 544 (1970) (same); Rule 220(c), SCACR (appellate court may affirm for any reason appearing in the record). Â Accordingly, we affirm.Â  We decline to exercise our discretion to avoid application of the procedural bar.Â  See Joiner ex rel. Rivas v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 107, 536 S.E.2d 372, 374 (2000) (â€œprocedural rules are subservient to the courtâ€™s duty to zealously guard the rights of minorsâ€); Ex parte Roper, 254 S.C. 558, 563, 176 S.E.2d 175, 177 (1970) (duty to protect rights of minors has precedence over procedural rules otherwise limiting the scope of review and matters affecting the rights of minors may be considered by an appellate court for the first time on appeal or even on its own motion); Galloway v. Galloway, 249 S.C. 157, 160, 153 S.E.2d 326, 327 (1967) (same).
CONCLUSION
It is error, in the face of a request by a party for an evidentiary hearing, for the family court to issue a permanency planning order based on an examination of the file and pleadings, the arguments of counsel, and the GALâ€™s report, but without considering testimony and evidence at a hearing where witnesses are subject to direct and cross-examination.Â  Although we find error, we affirm the order of the family court because Custodian failed to appeal the ruling which dismissed her from the case.
 AFFIRMED IN RESULT.
TOAL, C.J., and MOORE, J., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurring in result only.Â  WALLER, J., not participating.

[1]Â  None of the attorneys moved to submit any written documents into evidence during their descriptions of the case, although they mentioned some documents.Â  No party has objected to inclusion of the documents in the record on appeal.Â  See Rule 210(c), SCACR.
[2]Â  The family court judge properly may reject a temporary custodianâ€™s effort to obtain or retain custody of a child due to the custodianâ€™s failure to comply with a treatment and placement plan, but the custodian retains standing to challenge that decision in the family court and on appeal.

title: State v. Haase
description: The issue on appeal in this case is whether or not the circuit court erred in reversing Haaseâ€™s conviction due to the failure of police to follow the procedures mandated by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2934.
text:
Haase


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Appellant,
v.
Alicia Jeanette Haase, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26093
Heard November 30, 2005 - Filed January 9, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., of Columbia, and Jerry W. Peace, of Greenwood, for Appellant. 
John W. Carrigg, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:  Alicia Jeanette Haase, was convicted of driving under the influence (DUI) in municipal court in Greenwood County.Â  On appeal, the circuit court reversed her conviction, holding the state had failed to comply with S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2934 (Supp. 2004) at the time of her arrest.Â  We reverse and reinstate the conviction.[1]
FACTS
Haaseâ€™s vehicle was observed speeding and jumping a curb at 3:00 a.m. on September 28, 2001, in Greenwood.Â  Nearby police heard her car jump the curb and proceeded to the parking lot where Haaseâ€™s vehicle had stopped.Â  Â Haase smelled of alcohol, had slurred speech, and was unsteady on her feet.Â  After failing several sobriety tests, she was arrested for DUI and taken to the detention center for a Data Master test.Â  Haase was read her Miranda[2] rights and given Implied Consent warnings,[3] but refused the Data Master test.Â  
Haase was tried in municipal court in January 2004.Â  She moved to exclude evidence of her refusal to take the Data Master test, claiming the arresting officer failed to comply with S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2934.Â  The motion was denied, and the jury convicted Haase of DUI.Â  Haase appealed, and the circuit court ruled the stateâ€™s failure to comply with S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2934 required exclusion of all evidence against Haase which arose after her arrest, thereby requiring reversal of her conviction.[4] Â Â 
ISSUE
Did the circuit court err in reversing Haaseâ€™s conviction due to the failure to follow the procedures mandated by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2934? 
DISCUSSION
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2934, which became effective March 1, 2002, is entitled â€œRight to Compulsory Process,â€ and provides for the right to compulsory process for obtaining witnesses and documents.Â  In addition, Â§ 56-5-2934 provides, in pertinent part:

In addition, at the time of arrest for a violation of Section 56-5-2930, 56-5-2933, or 56-5-2945, the arresting officer, in addition to other notice requirements, must inform the defendant of his right to all hearings provided by law to include those if a breath test is refused or taken with a result that would require license suspension. The arresting officer, if the defendant wishes to avail himself of any such hearings, depending on the choices made or the breath test results obtained, must provide the defendant with the appropriate form to request the hearing or hearings. The defendant must acknowledge receipt of the notice requirements and receipt of the hearing form if such a hearing or hearings are desired.

2000 Act No. 390, Â§ 9, (emphasis supplied).Â  This section became effective March 1, 2002.Â  However, Section 34 of Act 390 made Â§ 56-5-2934 applicable to all pending cases that have not been adjudicated on that date.Â Â  Although Haase was arrested six months prior to the effective date of Â§ 56-5-2934, her case was not adjudicated until January 2004, such that it was pending on March 1, 2002.Â  
The circuit court ruled the state was required to comply with Â§ 56-5-2934 and, finding the state failed to do so, the court held all evidence against Haase which arose or was collected at or after her arrest must be excluded; accordingly, her conviction was reversed.Â  This was error.Â  We find Haase was adequately advised pursuant to Â§ 56-5-2934.
Haase was given Implied Consent warnings while at the Data Master site, prior to refusing the test.Â  Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950 (a) (the Implied Consent statute), these warnings would have advised Haase that her license would be suspended if she refused the test, and that she had the right to request an administrative hearing.Â  The purpose of the warnings under Â§ 56-5-2934 are to advise the defendant of the consequences of refusing or failing the breathalyzer, i.e., license suspension, and to advise the defendant of the right to a hearing concerning a suspension and provide the necessary forms to request such a hearing.Â  
Haase makes no claim that the warnings given were inadequate or improper.Â  Rather, she contends only that the failure to give the warnings at the arrest site mandates exclusion of all post-arrest evidence of her intoxication.Â  We disagree.Â  
In State v. Dowd, 306 S.C. 268, 269, 411 S.E.2d 428, 429 (1991), we held that â€œ[a]n arrest does not necessarily terminate the instant a person is taken into custody; arrest also includes bringing the person personally within the custody and control of the law.â€Â  We find police, by giving Haase warnings prior to her refusal of the Data Master test, sufficiently complied with the requirements of Â§ 56-5-2934.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court erred in reversing Haaseâ€™s conviction.Â  The judgment below is reversed.
 REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice J. Ernst Kinard, Jr., concur.

[1]Â  We certified this case from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  
[2]Â  Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966).
[3] Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950 (a).
[4] Â This evidence includes all statements made by Haase after her arrest, all observations by police officers made after the arrest, and the videotape made in preparation for administration of the Data Master test.

description: Appellant was convicted of murder and burglary in the first degree.  The Court held the trial judge properly admitted evidence emanating from Appellantâ€™s warrantless arrest.  The Court found the trial judge erred in refusing to suppress evidence of Appellantâ€™s blood because the order compelling the blood sample failed to comply with constitutional and statutory requirements.  The Court further found the trial court erred in admitting evidence seized from Appellantâ€™s residence because the issuing magistrate did not have a substantial basis to find probable cause for a search.  However, the Court held these errors were harmless and affirmed Appellantâ€™s convictions.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
John Roosevelt Baccus, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marion County
Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26094
Heard November 30, 2005 - Filed January 9, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of the South Carolina Office of Appellant Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Edgar L. Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  John Roosevelt Baccus (Appellant) was convicted of murder and burglary in the first degree in connection with the shooting death of Brenda Kay Godbolt (victim), his former girlfriend.Â  Appellant was sentenced to life imprisonment without parole on the murder charge and life imprisonment for the burglary charge, to be served concurrently.Â  We certified his appeal from the Court of Appeals, pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On November 14, 1999, the victim and her four-year old son were at her residence in Marion County.Â  Victim and her friend, Priscilla Ham, talked at length during two telephone conversations.Â  During the second conversation the victim began screaming.Â  Ham testified the victim screamed, â€œJohn was here.â€Â  Ham further testified she heard Appellant say, â€œIâ€™m gonna kill your ass.â€Â  She then heard a pop and clicking sound.Â  Ham reported the incident to 911.Â  
At trial, Dr. Erin Presnell, an expert in forensic pathology, testified the victim received two gunshot wounds to her body, one on her left cheek and one on her neck.Â  Death resulted from the gunshot wound to the cheek.Â  
At a pretrial suppression hearing and at trial, Officer Von Turbeville testified he arrived on the scene in the early morning hours of November 15, 1999, where he met with other officers and called Ham.Â  Ham relayed to Turbeville her phone conversation with the victim and what she had overheard.Â  Ham told him the victim said Appellant was coming through the window.Â  She also gave him Appellantâ€™s name, his address in Florence County, and the type of car he had been driving.Â  Turbeville relayed this information to Officer Barry Prosser of the Florence County Sheriffâ€™s Department.Â  
Prosser testified at trial and at the suppression hearing that he went to Appellantâ€™s residence, where he knocked on the door but received no response.Â  Prosser observed a car parked at a convenience store about one-fourth of a mile from Appellantâ€™s house that matched the description of the car Appellant had been driving.Â  He noticed a â€œred substanceâ€ on the car and inside it.Â  He also observed a smoldering burn pile containing clothing and shoes in Appellantâ€™s back yard.Â  He testified he knocked on the door again and Appellant answered.Â  Prosser advised Appellant he was investigating an incident in Marion County, and Appellant was arrested.Â  
At the pretrial suppression hearing, Turbeville testified he gave Officer Amber McDaniel of the Florence County Sheriffâ€™s Department information to obtain a search warrant for Appellantâ€™s residence.Â  At a subsequent pretrial suppression hearing, McDaniel testified Turbeville told her about a homicide in Marion County; that Prosser had arrested Appellant, a suspect, in Florence County; that there was a burn pile with clothing outside Appellantâ€™s residence and that a vehicle Appellant was allegedly driving appeared to have blood stains in it.Â  
McDaniel completed an affidavit for a search warrant with the information Turbeville supplied.Â  She testified she did not know any particulars regarding the homicide at the time she requested a search warrant; specifically, she did not know why Appellant was a suspect.Â  Additionally, she told the magistrate she had received a phone call from Turbeville regarding a homicide and Appellant had been arrested.Â  She did not remember telling the magistrate anything not contained in the affidavit for the search warrant.Â  Upon executing the search warrant, clothing, shoes, and a key to a vehicle were seized from Appellantâ€™s residence.Â  
Prior to trial, the State petitioned the circuit court and the court issued an order directing Appellant to provide a blood sample for testing and comparison purposes.Â  Blood was drawn from Appellant pursuant to the order.Â  
The State presented the testimony of Michelle Dixon, who was qualified as an expert in latent prints, blood spatter, and crime scene reconstruction.Â  During her initial walk-through of the victimâ€™s house, Dixon testified she found the victim in the rear bedroom where a window had been broken.Â  She observed bloody footwear impressions from the bedroom to the side door of the residence.Â  She testified during the process of entering the window the suspect was cut.Â  She also testified fingerprints found in the window sill matched Appellantâ€™s fingerprints.Â  
John Black testified as an expert in crime scene analysis, fingerprints, blood, and footwear impressions.Â  He testified the shoes seized from Appellantâ€™s house matched the bloody shoeprints in the victimâ€™s house.
Dr. Steve Lambert testified at trial as an expert in DNA and serological analysis.Â  Lambert testified he compared Appellantâ€™s blood, drawn pursuant to a court order, with evidence found in the victimâ€™s home.Â  Lambert testified DNA testing and blood comparison revealed Appellantâ€™s blood matched blood found on the kitchen door, a bed sheet, and a blind in the bedroom where the victim was found.Â  He also testified that on the night of Appellantâ€™s arrest a blood swab was taken from a cut on Appellantâ€™s left palm.Â  The blood from that swabbing also matched the blood on the door, sheet, and blind. Â 
During the suppression hearing and again during trial, Appellant moved to suppress evidence on the following grounds: (1) any evidence obtained by the State as a result of Appellantâ€™s warrantless arrest because the arresting officer lacked probable cause; (2) any evidence obtained by the search warrant because the affidavit accompanying the search warrant lacked probable cause; and (3) blood evidence drawn pursuant to a court order and implicating Appellant in the crime because the bodily intrusion was an unlawful search and seizure.Â  The trial judge denied the motions.
ISSUES

  
    
      
        I. 
         Did the trial court err in admitting evidence emanating from Appellantâ€™s arrest because the police officer did not have probable cause to arrest him?
      
      
        
        
      
      
        II. 
         Did the trial court err in admitting evidence seized from Appellantâ€™s residence because the police affidavit which accompanied the search warrant did not support a finding of probable cause?
      
      
        
        
      
      
        III.    
         Did the trial court err in refusing to suppress blood evidence implicating Appellant in the crimes which was obtained in violation of his constitutional and statutory rights?Â 
      
    
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  This Court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 452, 527 S.E.2d 105, 111 (2000).Â  The trial judgeâ€™s factual findings on whether evidence should be suppressed due to a Fourth Amendment violation are reviewed for clear error.Â  State v. Brockman, 339 S.C. 57, 66, 528 S.E.2d 661, 665-66 (2000) (a private search is a question of fact and the trial courtâ€™s ruling will be reversed only if there is clear error). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Arrest
Appellant argues the trial court erred by refusing to suppress evidence seized emanating from his arrest.Â  Appellant contends his arrest was illegal because officers arrested him without a warrant and without probable cause.Â  Appellant argues his fingerprints and blood, which were taken at the jail after his allegedly illegal arrest, should be suppressed as the fruit of the poisonous tree. Â See Wong Sun v. United States, 371 U.S. 471, 83 S.Ct. 407 (1963).Â  We disagree.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The fundamental question in determining the lawfulness of an arrest is whether probable cause existed to make the arrest.Â  Probable cause for a warrantless arrest exists when the circumstances within the arresting officerâ€™s knowledge are sufficient to lead a reasonable person to believe that a crime has been committed by the person being arrested. Â State v. George, 323 S.C. 496, 509, 476 S.E.2d 903, 911 (1996) (finding probable cause for warrantless arrest for murder).Â  Whether probable cause exists depends upon the totality of the circumstances surrounding the information at the officerâ€™s disposal. Â Id.; see also Beck v. Ohio, 379 U.S. 89, 91, 85 S.Ct. 223, 225 (1964) (a court must consider â€œwhether, at the moment the arrest was made, the officers had probable cause to make it‑‑whether at that moment the facts and circumstances within their knowledge and of which they had reasonably trustworthy information were sufficient to warrant a prudent man in believing that the [Appellant] had committed. . .an offense.â€).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
We conclude Prosser had probable cause to make the warrantless arrest based on the information he received from Turbeville and his own observations at Appellantâ€™s residence.Â  Turbeville testified he relayed to Prosser information he received from Ham.Â  Prosser testified Turbeville informed him of a homicide and information related to that homicide.Â  He knew Appellant was a suspect in the homicide.Â  He also observed a red substance on the inside and outside of a car matching the description of the car Appellant had been driving.Â  He saw a burn pile containing shoes and clothing in Appellantâ€™s backyard.Â  The trial judge properly admitted evidence emanating from Appellantâ€™s warrantless arrest.Â  
II. Search Warrant
Appellant argues the trial court erred by refusing to suppress evidence seized from his residence pursuant to a search warrant.Â  Appellant contends the search warrant was not supported by probable cause, and the shoes, clothing, and key seized should have been excluded from trial.[1]Â  We agree.Â Â  
A search warrant may issue only upon a finding of probable cause. State v. Bellamy, 336 S.C. 140, 143, 519 S.E.2d 347, 348 (1999). The duty of the reviewing court is to ensure the issuing magistrate had a substantial basis upon which to conclude that probable cause existed.Â  State v. Adams, 291 S.C. 132, 352 S.E.2d 483 (1987).Â  In Illinois v. Gates, 462 U.S. 213, 238, 103 S.Ct. 2317, 2332 (1983), the United States Supreme Court adopted a â€œtotality-of-the-circumstancesâ€ test for probable cause determinations:
                                                                   

The task of the issuing magistrate is simply to make a practical,
common-sense decision whether, given all the circumstances set forth in the affidavit before him, including the â€œveracityâ€ and
â€œbasis of knowledgeâ€ of persons supplying hearsay information, there is a fair probability that contraband or evidence of a crime
will be found in a particular place.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

In South Carolina, search warrants may be issued â€œonly upon affidavit sworn to before the magistrate. . .establishing the grounds for the warrant.â€Â  S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140 (2003); see also State v. McKnight, 291 S.C.110, 352 S.E.2d 471 (1987). The affidavit must set forth particular facts and circumstances underlying the existence of probable cause to allow the magistrate to make an independent evaluation of the matter.Â  Franks v. Delaware, 438 U.S. 154, 98 S.Ct. 2674 (1978). Â 
In State v. Smith, 301 S.C. 371, 392 S.E.2d 182 (1990), Smith moved to suppress a knife, allegedly used in a robbery, which was seized from his motel room pursuant to a search warrant.Â  In determining whether the issuing magistrate had a substantial basis to conclude probable cause existed, this Court considered the following affidavit accompanying a search warrant:

That on May 12th at approximately 11:45 p.m. Reginald Jerome
Smith went into the Master Inn located at 1468 Savannah Hwy., Charleston, S.C. and he then robbed the manager at knife point.
Smith has been staying at the Host of America Room 216 since Jan. 1, 1988 and there is every reason to believe the weapon and
clothes used in the robbery will be located in the room. This information was confirmed in person by Sgt. Sherman on
05/13/88. 

Id. at 372, 392 S.E.2d at 183.Â  We held that the affidavit was defective because it â€œset[] forth no facts as to why police believed Smith robbed the Master Host Inn.â€Â  Id. at 373, 392 S.E.2d at 183. We further found, â€œMere conclusory statements which give the magistrate no basis to make a judgment regarding probable cause are insufficient.â€Â  Id.Â  See also State v. Weston, 329 S.C. 287, 494 S.E.2d 801 (1997) (an affidavit supporting a search warrant could not have provided a substantial basis for finding probable cause to search Westonâ€™s car when the affidavit failed to set forth any facts as to why police believed Weston committed the crime and the first three sentences of the affidavit contained conclusory statements).Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In the present case, the affidavit in support of the search warrant for Appellantâ€™s residence read:

DESCRIPTION OF PROPERTY SOUGHT
 Any evidence such as: clothing, shoes, weapons, or forensics evidence such as blood.Â  Which maybe connected with the
Homicide of Brenda K. Godbolt which occurred in Marion County. . . .
REASON FOR AFFIANTâ€™S BELIEF THAT THE PROPERTY SOUGHT IS ON THE SUBJECT PREMISES
 At the time of the suspects (sic) arrest at 2616 Alligator Rd. in Florence County, by Investigators Barry Prosser and Von Dean
Turbeville with Florence and Marion County Sheriffâ€™s Office.Â  A pile of what appeared to be clothing was lying on the ground
beside the residence smoldering in plain view, and a vehicle the suspect was apparently driving was located approximately Â¼ of a
mile from this residence with blood stains on the inside and outside of the vehicle.Â 

This affidavit fails to set forth any facts as to why police believed Appellant committed the crime.Â  The language in the affidavit lacks specifity and contains conclusory statements.Â  Given the totality of the circumstances, we conclude the issuing magistrate did not have a substantial basis to find probable cause for a search of Appellantâ€™s residence, and the trial court erred in admitting evidence seized pursuant to the search warrant.Â  
III. Bodily Intrusion
Appellant argues the trial court erred by refusing to suppress
blood evidence implicating him in the crime.Â  Specifically, Appellant contends the court order compelling a blood sample violated the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140, and Schmerber v. California, 384 U.S. 757, 86 S.Ct. 1826 (1966).Â  We agree. 
Appellant argues the petition and order do not meet constitutional or statutory requirements because there was no sworn testimony, warrant, or affidavit showing probable cause that a search of Appellantâ€™s body would produce admissible evidence.Â  The State asserts Appellant consented to have his blood drawn and tested by filing a motion to compel evidence under a previously filed Brady[2] motion. The State further contends if the search is deemed nonconsensual, then the search was valid because the petition and order were the functional equivalent of a search warrant. 
The Stateâ€™s assertion that Appellant consented to a search is without merit.Â  A defendant does not consent to a search and seizure by filing a Brady motion.Â  
The Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures.Â  An order issued pursuant to Â§ 17-13-140 that allows the government to procure evidence from a personâ€™s body constitutes a search and seizure under the Fourth Amendment. Schmerber, 384 U.S. at 767-70, 86 S.Ct. at 1834-35; State v. Register, 308 S.C. 534, 419 S.E.2d 771 (1992).Â  The Fourth Amendment protects against intrusions into the human body for the taking of evidence absent a warrant unless there are exigent circumstances, such as the imminent destruction of
evidence Schmerber, 384 U.S. at 770, 86 S.Ct. at 1835; see also State v. Dupree, 319 S.C. 454, 462 S.E.2d 279 (1995) (applying Schmerber analysis to search of suspectâ€™s mouth).Â  Where blood is needed only to determine blood type to match existing evidence, a warrant must be obtained even though there has been a lawful arrest.Â  Gantt v. State, 354 S.C. 183, 580 S.E.2d 133 (2003). 
A court order issued pursuant to Â§ 17-13-140 that allows the
government to procure evidence from a personâ€™s body must comply with constitutional and statutory guidelines.Â  Schmerber, 384 U.S. at 769-70, 86 S.Ct. at 1835; In re Snyder, 308 S.C. 192, 417 S.E.2d 572, (1992); Register, 308 S.C. at 537, 419 S.E.2d at 772.Â  In Snyder, we stated:Â 

Section 17-13-140 covers â€œthe issuance, execution and return of
search warrants for property connected with the commission of crime. . .â€ Subsection (4) provides for the issuance of a searchwarrant for â€œproperty constituting evidence of crime or tending toshow that a particular person committed a criminal offense.â€Under this courtâ€™s construction, â€œpropertyâ€ as used in Section
17-13-140, encompasses nontestimonial identification evidence.
 Respondents next assert that Section 17-13-140 contains no
guidelines and procedures for obtaining nontestimonial identification evidence. However, guidelines and procedures for
acquiring such evidence were promulgated in the case of In re: An Investigation into the Death of Abe A., 56 N.Y.2d 288, 452
N.Y.S.2d 6, 7, 437 N.E.2d 265, 266 (1982). David M. v. Dwyer, 484 N.Y.S.2d 323, 107 A.D.2d 884 (1985) [citing Matter of Abe A., supra.] established considerations for determining whether or
not there exists probable cause to permit the acquisition of such evidence. These elements are: 
 (1) probable cause to believe the suspect has committed the crime, 
 (2) a clear indication that relevant material evidence will be found, and 
 (3) the method used to secure it is safe and reliable.
 Additional factors to be weighed are the seriousness of the crime and the importance of the evidence to the investigation. The
judge is required to balance the necessity for acquiring involuntary nontestimonial identification evidence against
constitutional safeguards prohibiting unreasonable bodily intrusions, searches, and seizures. Id.Â  . . .
We construe Section 17-13-140 to provide for the involuntary
submission of nontestimonial identification evidence. Further, this Court holds that upon a sufficient showing of probable cause
for the issuance of an order, a court may order that such evidence be obtained from unarrested suspects within guidelines mandated
under the statutory provisions, case law, and Constitutional laws of this State and of the United States. Â 

308 S.C. at 195-96, 417 S.E.2d at 573-74; see also Register, 308 S.C. at 537-38, 419 S.E.2d at 773 (setting forth essentially the same considerations for a warrant or order compelling a bodily intrusion into a potential witness).
The facts of the present case are similar to Snyder and Register because the Fourth Amendment protections apply even when an individual has been arrested and indicted.Â  See Gantt, 354 S.C. at 187, 580 S.E.2d at 135 (â€œA lawful arrest does not in itself justify a warrantless search that requires bodily intrusion.â€). Therefore, a court order allowing the State to procure evidence from an arrested and indicted suspect must meet statutory and constitutional guidelines.Â  
Under both the United States and South Carolina constitutions, search warrants may not be issued except â€œupon probable cause, supported by Oath or affirmation.â€ U.S. Const. amend. IV; S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 10.Â  Following these constitutional requirements, Â§ 17-13-140 requires a sworn affidavit for a search warrant to be issued.Â  A court order issued pursuant to Â§ 17-13-140, which stands in place of a search warrant, should only be issued upon a finding of probable cause, which is supported by oath or affirmation. [3]Â  Nothing in the record suggests the court order was issued upon a finding of probable cause supported by oath or affirmation.Â  Furthermore, exigent circumstances did not exist to justify a bodily intrusion without a warrant or order issued under Â§ 17-13-140.Â  Compare Schmerber, 384 U.S. at 770-71, 86 S.Ct. at 1826 (exigent circumstances existed when testing for blood alcohol level, which is considered subject to imminent destruction).Â  We conclude the trial judge erred in refusing to suppress evidence of Appellantâ€™s blood because the order fails to comply with constitutional and statutory requirements.Â  See State v. Khingratsaiphon, 352 S.C. 62, 69, 572 S.E.2d 456, 459 (2002) (â€œEvidence seized in violation of the Fourth Amendment must be excluded from trial.â€).Â  
Having found error, we must ask what other evidence was considered besides the evidence entered in error. State v. Parker, 315 S.C. 230, 433 S.E.2d 831 (1993); see also Rule 220(c), SCACR (on appeal this court may affirm on any ground contained in the record).Â  When guilt is conclusively proven by competent evidence, such that no other rational conclusion could be reached, this Court will not set aside a conviction for insubstantial errors not affecting the result. Â State v. Livingston, 282 S.C. 1, 317 S.E.2d 129 (1984).Â  
The State presented the testimony of Ham who overheard Appellant tell the victim he was going to kill her and who overheard a pop and clicking sound.Â  Additionally, the State presented evidence that Appellantâ€™s fingerprints matched fingerprints on the window sill of the broken window in the victimâ€™s bedroom.Â  Also, Dr. Lambert testified the blood sample collected from Appellant on the night of his arrest matched the blood found on the swabs and cuttings from the door, blind, and sheet in the victimâ€™s house.Â  Therefore, the blood evidence drawn pursuant to the court order which should have been excluded was cumulative. See State v. Haselden, 353 S.C. 190, 577 S.E.2d 445 (2003) (admission of improper evidence is harmless where the evidence is merely cumulative to other evidence.); State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993) (any error in admission of evidence cumulative to other unobjected-to evidence is harmless).Â  After reviewing the entire record, we find the errors in admitting evidence from the search warrant and the court order were harmless.Â  SeeÂ  State v. Pickens, 320 S.C. 528, 466 S.E.2d 364 (1996) (â€œ[W]here a review of the entire record establishes the error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt, the conviction should not be reversed.â€).
CONCLUSION
The trial judge properly admitted evidence emanating from Appellantâ€™s warrantless arrest.Â  However, the trial judge erred in admitting evidence seized from Appellantâ€™s residence pursuant to the search warrant and in admitting blood evidence drawn by court order.Â  However, we conclude these errors were harmless and we affirm Appellantâ€™s convictions.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., concur.

[1]Â  At trial, Appellant also argued the search warrant should be suppressed because the warrant predated the crime and the warrant did not have the exact date and time of issuance and return.Â  The trial judge denied the motion to suppress on this ground.Â  Appellant has abandoned this argument on appeal.Â  See State v. Hiott, 276 S.C. 72, 276 S.E.2d 163 (1981); Rule 208(b)(1)(B), (D), SCACR (issue not argued in brief is deemed abandoned and precludes consideration on appeal).
[2]Â  Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83, 83 S.Ct. 1194 (1963).
[3] Â Appellant argues a search warrant must also be issued, but in Snyder and Register we recognized a court order may be issued under Â§ 17-13-140 instead of a search warrant.
