title: Dearybury v. State
description: Petitioner was convicted of criminal domestic violence and denied PCR.  The Court remanded for a hearing to determine whether Petitioner knowingly and voluntarily proceeded pro se at trial.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Dan A. Dearybury, Petitioner,
v.
State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Donald W. Beatty, Post-Conviction Relief Judge

Opinion No. 26095
Submitted December 1, 2005 - Filed January 9, 2006

REMANDED


  
    
      
Gloria Y. Leevy, of Leevy Law Firm, of Columbia, for
Petitioner. 
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief DeputyAttorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy
Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Molly Crum, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Petitioner was convicted of criminal domestic violence (CDV) in municipal court.Â  No direct appeal was taken.Â  Almost four years later, Petitioner filed an application for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  The PCR court denied Petitioner relief. Â We remand for a hearing to determine whether Petitioner knowingly and voluntarily proceeded pro se at trial.
FACTUAL / PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In August 1996, Petitioner and his wife were separated and had filed for divorce.Â  Petitioner retained an attorney to represent him in the divorce action.Â  Shortly thereafter, on September 10, 1996, Petitioner was arrested for CDV for an incident involving his wife.[1]Â  After being arrested, Petitioner testified, he called his divorce attorney from the city jail. Â Petitioner testified that his divorce attorney told him to plead not guilty and request a jury trial at the bond hearing, which he did.Â  
He testified that two days before a roll call, his divorce attorney told Petitioner that he would not be present.Â  Petitioner testified he appeared atÂ  the roll call and the trial judge asked him if he was ready to get started.Â Â  After Petitioner responded that he was, the trial began.Â  Petitioner was found guilty and sentenced.Â  Petitioner testified he did not object to going forward with the trial without counsel because he did not know what to say or do. 
Petitioner testified that afterwards he believed that his divorce attorney was taking steps to relieve him of the CDV conviction.Â  In December 2000, his divorce attorney withdrew as Petitionerâ€™s counsel in the divorce action.Â  In April 2001, Petitioner filed this action seeking relief from the CDV conviction.
Petitionerâ€™s divorce attorney testified at the PCR hearing that he never represented Petitioner in the CDV case.Â  He testified he was handling only Petitionerâ€™s divorce action.Â  He testified he did not remember Petitioner calling him from jail or advisingÂ  Petitioner to plead not guilty and request a jury trial.Â  Petitionerâ€™s divorce attorney testified he received a faxed copy of a letter from the clerk of court which stated Petitioner had requested a jury trial.Â  Several months later, he testified, he received a notice of a hearing in the CDV case.Â  Â Petitionerâ€™s divorce attorney testified he called the city prosecutor and advised her that he represented Petitioner only in the divorce action.Â  However, he asked that the CDV be continued because he hoped for a settlement in the divorce action.Â  The city prosecutor agreed and the CDV case was continued.Â  
Six months later, Petitionerâ€™s divorce attorney received a roster of cases from the city attorney indicating he represented Petitioner.Â  He testified he contacted Petitioner and advised him to obtain another attorney for the CDV case.Â  Petitionerâ€™s divorce attorney sent a letter to the city attorney advising that he was not representing Petitioner on the CDV charge.Â  He testified he did not discuss the matter any more with Petitioner until sometime in 2000.Â  
The PCR judge found Petitionerâ€™s divorce attorney was not Petitionerâ€™s trial counsel on the CDV offense and Petitioner was pro se at trial.Â  The PCR judge also found Petitionerâ€™s application for PCR was barred by the statute of limitations because Petitioner waited almost four years to file it.Â  The PCR judge additionally found that Petitioner was not entitledÂ  to a belated appeal pursuant to White v. State, 263 S.C. 110, 208 S.E.2d 35 (1974), because he held Petitioner was acting pro se and thus had waived any right to challenge the effectiveness of his counsel.Â  
ISSUES

1)Â  Did the PCR judge err in finding Petitioner acted pro se and was not entitled to a belated appeal pursuant
to White v. State? 
  2)Â  Did the PCR judge err in finding the statute of limitationsÂ barred Petitionerâ€™s PCR application? 
3) Did the trial court err in failing to sua sponte grant Petitioner a continuance?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Court will uphold the findings of the PCR judge when there is any evidence of probative value to support them. Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 525 S.E.2d 514 (2000); Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119, 386 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1989). The Court will not uphold the findings when there is no probative evidence to support them. Holland v. State, 322 S.C. 111, 470 S.E.2d 378 (1996).
LAW / ANALYSISÂ  
1) Belated Appeal
The PCR judge found Petitioner was acting pro se below and his failure to file a direct appeal was due to his own inaction.[2]Â  Â He also found Petitionerâ€™s divorce attorney was not Petitionerâ€™s trial counsel.Â  Petitioner contends this was error.Â  
Without a doubt, Petitioner appeared pro se at his trial.Â  The term "pro se" is a term so familiar to lawyers that it hardly needs to be defined. Â It simply means to represent oneself. Â See Black's Law Dictionary 1237 (7th ed. 1999).Â  Clearly, Petitioner represented himself at trial and thus was acting pro se.Â  Further, there is plenty of evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that Petitionerâ€™s divorce attorney was not Petitionerâ€™s trial counsel on the CDV offense. Â Cherry v. State, supra. Â While the issue was not precisely raised by Petitioner in his PCR application, the threshold question in this case is not whether Petitioner proceeded pro se but whether he knowingly and voluntarily proceeded pro se.[3]Â  
It is well-established that a defendant may waive the right to counsel and proceed pro se. Â Faretta v. California, 422 U.S. 806 (1975). Â Although a defendant's decision to proceed pro se may be to the defendant's own detriment, it "must be honored out of that respect for the individual which is the lifeblood of the law."Â  Id. at 834. Â The right to proceed pro se must be clearly asserted by the defendant prior to trial.Â  State v. Sims, 304 S.C. 409, 405 S.E.2d 377 (1991). Â The trial judge has the responsibility to ensure that the accused is informed of the dangers and disadvantages of self-representation, and makes a knowing and intelligent waiver of the right to counsel. Â Faretta, supra.
Whether Petitioner knowingly and voluntarily waived his right to counsel still needs to be determined.Â  If Petitioner did not knowingly and voluntarily waive his right to counsel, he is presumably entitled to a belated direct appeal.[4]Â  Accordingly, this issue is remanded.
2)Â  Statute of Limitations
The PCR judge found the statute of limitations barred Petitionerâ€™s PCR application.Â  Petitioner contends the PCR judge erred.Â  
A PCR application ordinarily "must be filed within one year after the entry of a judgment of conviction or within one year after the sending of the remittitur to the lower court from an appeal or the filing of the final decision upon an appeal, whichever is later." Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27- 45(A) (2003).Â  Petitioner contends his PCR application is governed by subsection (C) of Â§ 17-27- 45 which provides for a one-year statute of limitations from the time of discovery of material facts not previously presented and heard that require vacation of the conviction.Â  Petitioner contends that it was not until March 2001 that he discovered that his divorce attorney did not represent him on the CDV offense and he filed for PCR within one month.[5]Â  Petitioner then argues that because he did not waive his right to appeal, the statute of limitations does not apply.
As noted above, we affirm the PCR courtâ€™s finding that Petitionerâ€™s divorce attorney was not Petitionerâ€™s trial counsel on the CDV offense.Â  However, because a defendant has the right to be informed of the right to an appeal, Wilson v. State, 348 S.C. 215, 559 S.E.2d 581 (2002), this issue also boils down to whether Petitioner voluntarily waived his right to counsel.Â  If Petitioner did not voluntarily or knowingly waive his right to counsel, his PCR application would not be barred by the statute of limitations and he presumably would be entitled to relief.
The State also contends Petitionerâ€™s PCR application is barred by laches.Â  However, laches is an affirmative defense that must be pleaded pursuant to Rule 8(c), SCRCP. Â See also Adams v. B & D, Inc., 297 S.C. 416, 377 S.E.2d 315 (1989).Â  The State did not plead laches and accordingly is barred from asserting it now. 
3)     Continuance
Petitioner contends the trial judge should have sua sponte continued the case.Â  This is the direct appeal issue and because Petitioner was not granted a belated review, this issue is not properly before the Court at this time.Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we remand for the PCR judge to determine whether Petitioner knowingly and voluntarily waived his right to trial counsel.
REMANDED.
MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â  WALLER, J., not participating.

[1]The specific facts surrounding the CDV offense are not included in the record.
[2]Petitioner argues the PCR judge erred in finding that he waived his right to counsel.Â  However, the PCR judge merely found Petitioner was acting pro se.Â  The PCR judge did not address the voluntariness of the waiver.
[3]In his PCR application, Petitioner raised only the issue ofÂ  ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  He contends trial counsel was ineffective in failing to appear at trial and in failing to advise him of his rights, particularly the right to appeal.Â  In his PCR application, he raised only the issue of ineffective assistance of counsel. Â However, the issue of whether he voluntarily proceeded pro se was raised at the PCR hearing.Â  
[4]But see Walker v. State, 676 S.W.2d 460 (Ark. 1984)(fact that petitioner is proceeding pro se does not in itself constitute good cause for failure to conform to the prevailing rules of procedure).
[5]At the PCR hearing, Petitioner asserted that his divorce attorney represented him until sometime in 2000.Â  While his divorce attorney may have represented Petitioner in the divorce action until 2000, the evidence supports the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that his divorce attorney never represented Petitioner in the CDV action.Â

title: In the Matter of Scott L. Hood
description: This is an attorney disciplinary matter in which the Court imposed 1) a definite suspension as reciprocal discipline and 2) an indefinite suspensionas discipline for other matters.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Scott L.Hood, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26096
Submitted December 5, 2005 - Filed January 9, 2006

RECIPROCAL DEFINITE SUSPENSION
AND
INDEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Susan M. Johnston, Deputy Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
Scott L. Hood, pro se, of Irmo.  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  This matter is before the Court on a Petition for Reciprocal Discipline[1] and an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) entered into by the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent.[2]Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to either a two year definite suspension or an indefinite suspension from the practice of law.Â  We accept the agreement and indefinitely suspend respondent from the practice of law in this state.Â  Furthermore, we impose an eighteen (18) month suspension from the practice of law as reciprocal discipline.Â  The suspensions shall be served concurrently and shall run retroactively from the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension.[3]Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
I.
In December 2004, respondent was retained to represent Client Aâ€™s interest in a foreclosure action concerning property on which she held a judgment.Â  Client A paid respondent $375.00 and gave him her original documents.Â  Respondent sent her a filed copy of the Answer he had prepared but, subsequently, did not return any of her telephone calls and did not respond to the messages she left on his office door. Â Client A has not received a refund of her money or her original documents.Â  
II.
Client B retained respondent to file an appeal from a magistrateâ€™s court ruling in a civil suit against a car dealership.Â  Client B gave respondent $750.00 in fees and $100.00 in costs.Â  Respondent did not return Client Bâ€™s telephone calls for updates on her case.Â  Respondent closed his office and has refused to communicate with Client B.Â  Client B has since lost her car as well as the $850.00 she paid respondent.Â  
III.
Client C retained respondent to represent her in a consumer matter wherein Client C was wrongly reported to have filed for bankruptcy.Â  Client Câ€™s deposition was scheduled; without notice to her, respondent changed the deposition date.Â  Client C was unable to locate respondent for some time. Â Client Câ€™s deposition was subsequently taken.Â  Her legal matter has not been resolved.Â  
IV.
The United States Bankruptcy Court suspended respondent from filing new bankruptcy cases for a period of at least eighteen months, with conditions.Â  The Bankruptcy Court determined respondent had violated its rules regarding electronic filing and had perjured himself by attesting that his clients had signed the original documents when they had not.Â  Additionally, the Bankruptcy Court determined that several of respondentâ€™s cases had administrative deficiencies which had not been corrected.[4]Â Â  
V.
Respondent was paid $200.00 to update two (2) wills.Â  Respondent repeatedly missed appointments with the clients and did not prepare the wills or refund the fee.
VI.
Clients retained respondent to represent them in a bankruptcy filing.Â  Months later, respondent wrote and told the clients that their house might be foreclosed because they had not paid their mortgage.Â  The clients were unable to locate respondent during this period of time and are now unable to produce the large cash payment necessary to avoid foreclosure.Â  The clients are expecting to lose their home.Â  
VII.
Respondent failed to comply with a final decision of the Resolution of Fee Disputes Board directing him to pay a construction company $700.00.Â  The certificate of non-compliances is dated July 25, 2005.
VIII.
In November 2003, Client D retained respondent to handle a mortgage foreclosure.Â  In August 2004, respondent told Client D that he was waiting for a court date.Â  Client D received a letter from respondent dated June 30, 2005, in which respondent advised that the court had ruled on the foreclosure and his property would proceed to sale.Â  Respondent told Client D that the hearing was â€œlast minuteâ€ and he did not have time to contact Client D to advise him of the hearing.Â  Client D later learned from the Clerkâ€™s Office that the hearing notice was sent on May 27, 2005 and that the hearing was on June 30, 2005.Â  Client D hired another attorney and learned that respondent had agreed to the foreclosure sale without consulting with him.Â  
_____
Respondent admits that, while undertaking a career change, he did not take the action necessary to protect his clients during the transition.Â  Respondent asserts he does not believe he will ever desire to practice law again.Â  
Respondent states he consented to the Court placing him on interim suspension and that he has assisted the attorney appointed to protect his clientsâ€™ interests.Â  He further notes he signed a consent order with the Bankruptcy Court in which he agreed not to accept any new cases for a period of at least eighteen (18) months.Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that, by his misconduct, he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing clients); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep clients informed); Rule 1.5 (lawyer shall not charge excessive fee); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall promptly deliver to client any funds or other property to which client is entitled); Rule 3.2 (lawyer shall make reasonable efforts to expedite litigation consistent with the interests of his client); Rule 3.3 (lawyer shall not knowingly make a false statement of material fact or law to a tribunal); Rule 3.4(c) (lawyer shall not knowingly disobey an obligation under the rules of a tribunal); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the administration of justice).[5]
Â In addition, respondent admits his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline pursuant to Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers), Rule 7(a)(2) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct violating the applicable rules of professional conduct of another jurisdiction), Rule 7(a)(5) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession into disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law), and Rule 7(a)(10) (lawyer shall not willfully fail to comply with a final decision of the Resolution of Fee Disputes Board).Â  
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and indefinitely suspend respondent from the practice of law.Â  In addition, we suspend respondent from the practice of law for eighteen (18) months.Â  The suspensions shall be served concurrently and shall run retroactively from the date respondent was placed on interim suspension.Â  
Within thirty (30) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall pay restitution to all clients, other persons, and entities who have incurred losses as a result of respondentâ€™s misconduct in connection with this matter.Â  Within thirty (30) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall also reimburse the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection for any claims paid as a result of his misconduct in connection with this matter.Â  ODC shall advise the Court that respondent has paid the restitution required by this order.Â Â Â  Â Â 
Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall surrender his certificate of admission to practice law in this state to the Clerk of Court and shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413,
SCACR.
 DEFINITE SUSPENSION; INDEFINITE SUSPENSION.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â  WALLER, J., not participating.

[1] See Rule 29, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  
[2] See Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  
[3] See In the Matter of Hood, 365 S.C. 330, 618 S.E.2d 295 (2005).Â  
[4] The Petition for Reciprocal Discipline stems from the action by the Bankruptcy Court. Â Â 
[5] Respondentâ€™s misconduct occurred before the effective date of the Amendments to the Rules of Professional Conduct.Â  See Court Order dated June 20, 2005.Â  The Rules cited in this opinion are those which were in effect at the time of respondentâ€™s misconduct.Â

title: Buist v. Huggins
description: The issues on certiorari are whether the Court of Appeals properly held the Administrative Law Judge was without subject matter jurisdiction, and whether interest collected pursuant to S. C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-90 is properly calculated based on a flat fee, or on a per diem basis.
text:
Buist


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Thomas G. Buist, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Michael Huggins, in his capacity as Assessor for Charleston County, Peggy A. Moseley, in her capacity as Auditor for Charleston County, Andrew C. Smith, in his capacity as Treasurer for Charleston County, the Board of Assessment Appeals for Charleston County, and the County of Charleston, a political subdivision,
Respondents.
      
    
  



  
    
      
Worsley Co. Inc., As Assignee and Edgar A. Buck and Margaret B. Buck as Assignor and in their own rights as they may appear,
Petitioners,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Dorchester County Assessor and Dorchester County Auditor,
Respondents.
      
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Richland County
Â Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26097
Heard October 19, 2005 - Filed January 9, 2006

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
G. Trenholm Walker, Andrew K. Epting, Jr., and Amanda R. Maybank, all of Pratt-Thomas, Epting & Walker, PA, of Charleston, for Petitioners.
Bernard Eugene Ferrara, Jr., and Joseph Dawson, III, of N. Charleston, and John G. Frampton, of Chellis & Frampton, of Summerville, for Respondents.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision in Buist v. Huggins et. al., Op. No. 2003-UP-533 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Sept. 4, 2003), in which the Court of Appeals heldÂ  the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) lacked subject matter jurisdiction to review a countyâ€™s assessment of interest for the redemption of property from a delinquent tax sale pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-90 (2000).Â  We affirm in result, as modified.Â  
FACTS
Petitionersâ€™ properties were sold at delinquent tax sales.Â  Petitioners sought to redeem their properties pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-90 (2000).[1]
The Buist property was sold by Charleston County for $90,000.00 on October 7, 1996, as a result of $4520.88 in delinquent taxes owed.[2]Â  Buist redeemed the property on January 21, 1997.Â  To redeem the property, Buist was required to pay the back taxes owed, plus $678.00 late payment interest, a $100.00 levy fee, and $7200.00 â€œbidder interestâ€ pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-90,Â  calculated by County at 8% of the total amount of the successful bid on the property ($90,000 x 8%). Buist paid the $7200.00 bidder interest under protest, asserting that it should be calculated on a per diem basis, rather than assessed for an entire year.Â  Buist filed a claim for a refund pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-2560 with the County Board of Assessment Control.Â  The Charleston County Tax Refund Committee denied the request, and the Board of Assessment Appeals affirmed.Â  Buist filed a notice of appeal and request for a contested case hearing with the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) Division.Â  
Petitioner Worsley owed $4728.98 in taxes, penalties and costs, and his property was sold by Dorchester County for $153,000.00 on November 3, 1997.Â  Worsley redeemed the property on December 31, 1997.Â  To redeem the property, Worsley paid $4728.98 back taxes, plus $12,240.00 bidder interest, calculated by County at 8% of the total amount of the successful bid on the property ($153,000 x 8%), pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-90.Â  Worsley paid the $12,240.00 bidder interest under protest, and sought a refund under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-2560, claiming interest should be calculated on a per diem basis.Â  Dorchester County denied the request for refund. Â The Board of Assessment Appeals for Dorchester County denied the appeal, finding Â§ 12-60-2560 inapplicable to contest the interest paid to redeem real property.Â  Worsley filed a notice of appeal with the
ALJ. 
The same ALJ heard both the Buist and Worsley appeals.Â  The ALJ held that the legislature intended the term â€œinterestâ€ as used in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-90 to be used in its plain and ordinary terms, such that the counties should not be interpreting it to authorize a flat-rate interest â€œpenalty.â€Â  Accordingly, the ALJ found interest should be calculated on a per diem basis, entitling Buist and Worsley to a refund.Â  
Counties sought judicial review, and the cases were consolidated for a hearing.Â  The circuit court reversed, finding the ALJ was without jurisdiction over matters arising under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-40 et seq. (the Alternate Procedures Act).Â  The circuit court held the Revenue Procedures Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-2560, under which Petitioners had sought relief, was inapplicable to their claims for a refund.Â  The circuit court reasoned that the â€œinterestâ€ due under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-90 is not a â€œdisputed revenue liabilityâ€ so as to fall within the meaning of the section 12-60-20 of the Revenue Procedures Act.Â  It held the ALJ did not have jurisdiction to determine whether Counties properly calculated interest under Â§ 12-51-40 of the Alternate Procedures Act.Â  The circuit court lastly ruled that that the term â€œinterestâ€ as used in Â§ 12-51-90 was intended by the Legislature to constitute a â€œpenaltyâ€ such that the interest was properly calculated by Counties as a lump sum based upon the whole amount of the tax sale bid regardless of when the property was redeemed.Â  
The Court of Appeals affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s ruling that the ALJ was without jurisdiction to hear the appeal.Â  However, the Court of Appeals also held that because the ALJ lacked jurisdiction, the circuit court was likewise without jurisdiction to address the merits of the issue in its appellate capacity.Â  Accordingly, the Court of Appeals did not address the proper calculation of â€œinterestâ€ under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-90.Â  
ISSUES

1.Â  Did the Court of Appeals err in concluding the ALJ was without subject matter jurisdiction?
2.Â  Is the interest collected pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-90 properly calculated based on a flat fee, or on a per diem basis?

1.Â  JURISDICTION
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-40 et seq. sets forth an Alternate Procedure for collection of county taxes, authorizing counties to seize property and sell it at a delinquent tax sale.Â  Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-90, the defaulting taxpayer may redeem the property within one year of the tax sale by â€œpaying the person officially charged with the collection of delinquent taxes, assessments, penalties and costs, together with interest as provided in subsection B.â€[3]
Petitioners redeemed their properties within the first year, but challenged the countiesâ€™ calculation of the amount of interest.Â  Accordingly, they paid under protest and filed claims for refunds pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-2560, which is contained in the South Carolina Revenue Procedures Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-10 et seq.Â  It is undisputed that a claim for a â€œrefund of real property taxes assessed by the countyâ€ is made to the ALJ Division under Â§ 12-60-2560 of the Revenue Procedures Act.[4]Â  
Petitionersâ€™ citeÂ  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-80 of the Revenue Procedures Act, and this Courtâ€™s opinion in Brackenbrook v. County of North Charleston, 360 S.C. 390, 395, 602 S.E.2d 39, 42 (2004), in support of their claim that the ALJ had jurisdiction.Â  
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-80 provides, in part, â€œthere is no remedy other than those provided in this chapter in any case involving the illegal or wrongful collection of taxes, or attempt to collect taxes.â€[5]Â  This Court interpreted Â§ 12-60-80 in Brackenbrook.Â  There, taxpayers brought an action in circuit court alleging Charleston County levied an excessive millage rate on real property. The circuit court allowed the taxpayersâ€™ suit, finding taxpayers had no administrative remedies under the Revenue Procedures Act (RPA) because the Act did not cover taxpayer challenges to the countyâ€™s millage rate determination. The circuit court concluded the RPAâ€™s mandated administrative remedies only applied to taxpayer challenges to a countyâ€™s â€œproperty tax assessment.â€Â  Because the taxpayers in Brackenbrook did not dispute any component of their property tax assessment, the circuit court held they had an immediate right to bring suit in circuit court. A majority of this Court reversed, holding that:

While the Act contains many specific procedures for taxpayers challenging their [property tax assessments], relief under the Act is not limited to these types of protests. Section 12-60-2530(A) specifically provides the board of assessment appeals may rule on any PTA dispute and also other relevant claims of a legal or factual nature except claims relating to property tax exemptions.

360 S.C. at 398, 602 S.E.2d at 44.Â  (emphasis supplied).Â  
Two justices dissented in Brackenbrook, finding the administrative remedy set forth in Â§ 12-60-2560 applicable only to challenges to property tax assessments, but not to challenges to the proper millage rate to be applied in calculating the amount of tax due.Â  Accordingly, the dissent would have held the administrative remedy limitation in Â§ 12-60-80Â  did not control.
The circuit court in this case, as well as the Court of Appeals, found that Petitionersâ€™ claims did not involve a challenge to a property tax assessment but, rather, a claim for a refund of interest paid to the Delinquent Tax Collector,[6] and that the only provisions governing redemption of property sold at a delinquent tax sale were found in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-90, so as to fall within the Alternate Procedures Act, requiring suit to be brought in the circuit court. Â We agree. 
Unlike Brackenbrook, Petitioners in this case challenge neither their underlying tax assessments, nor their millage rates.Â  Rather, Petitioners challenge only the calculation of interest under Â§ 12-51-90.Â  While their interest payment could feasibly be lowered, the underlying tax amount owed is not disputed.Â  Accordingly, we find their challenge is properly brought under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-90, such that the Alternate Procedures Act controls. Â The Court of Appeals properly held jurisdiction over such disputes remains in the circuit court, and the ALJ was without jurisdiction.[7]  
2.Â  CALCULATION OF INTEREST[8]
As noted previously, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-90 permits a defaulting taxpayer to redeem property within one year of a delinquent tax sale and sets forth the interest to be paid.Â  As it read at the time these properties were redeemed, Â§ 12-51-90 provided that a defaulting taxpayer could redeem the property upon payment of the â€œdelinquent taxes, assessments, penalties and costs, together with eight percent interest on the whole amount of the delinquent tax sale bid. . . . In the case of a redemption in the last six months of the redemption period, . . . the applicable rate of interest is twelve percent.â€Â  Emphasis supplied.[9]Â Â  
If a statuteâ€™s language is plain, unambiguous, and conveys a clear meaning â€œthe rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and the court has no right to impose another meaning.â€ Â Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  The words of the statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statute's operation.Â 
Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992).Â  The cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.Â  Hawkins v. Bruno Yacht Sales, Inc., 353 S.C. 31, 39, 577 S.E.2d 202, 207 (2003).
The construction of a statute by the agency charged with its administration will be accorded the most respectful consideration and will not be overruled absent compelling reasons.Â  Brown v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 515, 560 S.E.2d 410, 414 (2002) (quoting Dunton v. South Carolina Bd. of Examiners in Optometry, 291 S.C. 221, 223, 353 S.E.2d 132, 133 (1987)); see also Nucor Steel v. South Carolina Public Serv. Commâ€™n, 310 S.C. 539, 543, 426 S.E.2d 319, 321 (1992) (where an agency is charged with the execution of a statute, the agencyâ€™s interpretation should not be overruled without cogent reason).
It is undisputed that counties have uniformly been collecting a flat rate of interest on redeemed properties.Â  Further, under a plain reading of the statute, it is clear the Legislature intended to impose a flat-fee interest rate of 8% on property redeemed within the first six months, and a 12% rate for the last six months.Â  In light of the wording of the statute that the interest is charged on the whole amount of the delinquent tax sale bid, and the fact that the rate increases to 12% if not paid within the first 6 months, it is patent that the Legislature intended a flatÂ  rate of interest.Â  This result is bolstered by the recent amendments to Â§ 12-51-90, as shown in footnote 9, which imposes a different interest rate depending upon which quarter the property is redeemed (3%, 6%, 9% and 12%).Â  See Cotty v. Yartzeff, 309 S.C. 259, 422 S.E.2d 100 (1992) (subsequent statutory amendment may be interpreted as clarifying original legislative intent).Â  We find nothing in the language of Â§ 12-51-90 indicating a legislative intent that interest be paid on a per diem basis.Â  
Petitioners cite S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-54-25(D), governing the interest due on late taxes, and the applicable tax rate, which states that â€œthe rate of interest on underpayments and overpayments is established by the department in the same manner and at the same time as the underpayment rate provided in Internal Revenue Code Sections 6621(a)(2) and 6622.â€Â  Under IRC Code 6622, interest is compounded daily.Â  The compounding of interest under Â§ 12-54-25(D) is inapplicable here.Â  Section 12-51-90 does not deal with the late payment of taxes but, rather, the redemption of property sold at a delinquent tax sale.Â  Further, the Legislature saw fit, in Â§ 12-54-25(D) to set forth a federal tax code section upon which interest would be based.Â  Had the Legislature intended interest under section 12-51-90 to be compounded as set forth in the IRC, it could have plainly said so.Â  See Tilley v. Pacesetter, 333 S.C. 33, 508 S.E.2d 16 (1998) (if legislature had intended a certain result in statute it would have said so).[10] Â Â The circuit court correctly held Â§ 12-51-90 imposes a flat rate interest fee.
CONCLUSION
We affirm the Court of Appealsâ€™ ruling that the ALJ lacked jurisdiction over Petitionersâ€™ claims.Â  We also affirm the circuit courtâ€™s ruling that Petitioners were properly charged a flat rate of interest. 
 AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur. 

[1]Â  The cases were consolidated for appeal and involve two separate properties; the Worsley property located in Dorchester County, and the Buist property located on Kiawah Island in Charleston County.
[2]Â  Buist is the attorney for the property owners, Michael and Sharon Mayberry.
[3] Â The amount of interest is addressed in Issue 2 below.Â  
[4]Â  As noted by the majority of the Court in Brackenbrook v. County of North Charleston, 360 S.C. 390, 395, 602 S.E.2d 39, 42 (2004), â€œthe General Assembly adopted the South Carolina Revenue Procedures Act (the Act) to provide the people of this State with a straight forward procedure to determine any disputed revenue liability.â€
[5]  Â An exception is provided for cases involving the constitutionality of a statute.
[6]Â  The circuit court was persuaded by the fact that the taxes are required by Â§Â§ 12-51-40 through 12-51-60 to be paid to the delinquent tax collector, rather than the auditor.
[7] Â This result is buttressed by the fact that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-2560 (under which the ALJâ€™s jurisdiction in this case is premised) requires a taxpayer to seek a refund â€œby filing a claim for refund with the county assessor who made the property tax assessment for the property for which the tax refund is sought.â€Â  Here, the assessment of interest was made by the Delinquent Tax Collector rather than the county assessor.
[8]Â  In light of our ruling on the subject matter jurisdiction issue, we would not normally address this issue.Â  However, because the circuit court has already addressed this issue, and in the interest of judicial economy, we proceed to review the proper calculation of interest. 
[9]Â  The statute has been amended several times since its adoption in 1962.Â  Each version of the statute, however, has included terminology that the interest is to be â€œon the whole amount of the delinquent tax sale bid.Â  Section 12-51-90 was most recently amended in 2000 and now reads:Â  The lump sum amount of interest due on the whole amount of the delinquent tax sale based on the month during the redemption period the property is redeemed and that rate relates back to the beginning of the redemption period according to the following schedule: 

  
    
      
        Month of Redemption Period:
         Amount of Interest Imposed:
      
      
        First three months       
         three percent of the bid amount 
      
      
        Months four, five, and six  
         six percent of the bid amount 
      
      
        Months seven, eight, and
          nine    
         nine percent of the bid amount 
      
      
        Last three
          months     
         twelve percent of the bid
          amount
      
    
  

[10] Â Interestingly, at the time of this action, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 34-31-20 stated that â€œ. . . in all cases wherein any sum or sums of money shall be ascertained and, being due, shall draw interest according to law, the legal interest shall be at the rate of eight and three-fourths percent per annum.â€Â  Emphasis supplied.Â

text:
Weston


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Jeffrey J. Weston, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26099
Heard November 3, 2005 - Filed January 17, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Jeffrey A. Jacobs, Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER: Appellant, Jeffrey Weston, was convicted of murdering his mother, whose body was never found.Â  He was sentenced to forty years in prison.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In late 1997, at age 38, Weston went to live with his mother, Frances Franchey, at her Harbison apartment.Â  Franchey, in her late seventies, was a retired educator.Â  According to Francheyâ€™s friends, during the months Weston lived with her, she became â€œvery depressed, down, sad, agitated, nervous, very upset.â€Â  The manager of the apartment complex testified that Franchey did not want Weston to live with her and was terrified of him.Â  Shortly before her disappearance, Franchey talked about having Weston move out of her apartment.Â  On Tuesday, August 4, 1998, Franchey told her bridge partner, Suzanne Allen, she was going to ask Weston to leave.Â  
Franchey was last seen alive on August 6, 1998.Â  That same day, Mark Jordan, the maintenance supervisor for the apartment complex, noticed that the trunk to Mrs. Francheyâ€™s car was open, and was lined with clear plastic.[1]Â  Jordan testified he had never seen Weston driving Francheyâ€™s vehicle prior to her disappearance, but that Weston was driving it on Monday, August 10th.[2]Â  Jordan also testified that Franchey did not want bumper stickers on her car but that, shortly after her disappearance, a new bumper sticker appeared on the car which read, â€œMy kid beat up your honor roll student.â€Â  
Randy Myers, a resident of the apartment complex, testified that, at 4:30 a.m. on Saturday, August 8th, he saw Weston loading garbage bags into the trunk of Francheyâ€™s car.Â  The same day, Leslie Fuller, the apartment complex manager, received a phone call from a concerned friend of Franchey.Â  Fuller went to check on Franchey and, receiving no answer, she went around back to the patio where she saw that all of Francheyâ€™s plants were turned over, and there was an empty bleach bottle on the porch.Â  The next day, Fuller called Kathy Jarvis, a Richland County sheriffâ€™s deputy who lived at the complex and worked as its courtesy officer.Â  Fuller and Jarvis went to the apartment and found Weston home.Â  They saw Francheyâ€™s purse and glasses on her bed and were told by Weston that Franchey had â€œmet some man and run off with himâ€ leaving him a note on the coffee table.[3]Â Â  According to Fuller, Weston came into her office a day or two later, very disheveled, sweating profusely, his eyes huge, and stated, â€œI was really angry with my mother and now Iâ€™m just scared.â€Â  
On Monday, August 10th, Kathy Jarvis filed a missing personâ€™s report.Â  The same day, a Richland County sheriffâ€™s deputy, Michael Kalec, went to the apartment and spoke with Weston.Â  At that time, Kalec noticed there was no curtain in Francheyâ€™s bathroom.Â  Weston advised Kalec that his motherâ€™s purse and keys were missing.Â  Kathy Jarvis went to the apartment with police investigators on August 12th and noticed Francheyâ€™s purse was on the bed; she also noticed a brand new shower curtain was hanging in Francheyâ€™s bathroom.Â  
The sheriffâ€™s department continued its investigation throughout the month of August.Â  On September 4th, they returned to the apartment, which Weston had since vacated, and saw that the linoleum in the kitchen had been torn out, as well as a piece of the living room carpet.Â  An area rug was covering the hole in the carpet.[4]Â  It was not torn out by either the sheriffâ€™s department or apartment complex personnel.Â  Police tested the floor where the linoleum had been removed and found blood; blood was also found on drag marks leading from the hole in the carpet.Â  Investigators subsequently tested a piece of blood-stained molding from the apartment; the blood on the molding was Francheyâ€™s.Â  
On August 9, 2000, Weston was indicted for the murder of his mother; he was apprehended in Seattle, Washington in October 2000.Â  The defense put up no evidence at trial.Â  The jury found Weston guilty, and he was sentenced to forty years imprisonment.Â  
ISSUES
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  1.Â  Did the court err in allowing Suzanne Allen to testify as to the change in Francheyâ€™s demeanor after Weston came to live with her, and in allowing Francheyâ€™s daughter to testify as to her motherâ€™s fear of Weston? 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  2.Â  Did the court err in allowing the solicitor to question the apartment manager, Fuller, as to whether anyone other than Weston had any animosity toward Franchey?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  3.Â  Did the court err in allowing a police officer to testify that, other than Weston, she had never had anybody blankly stare at her and not respond to her questions?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  4.Â  Did the court err in allowing testimony to the effect that Weston stated, â€œI need a lawyerâ€ upon finding a search warrant the police had left inside his storage unit?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  5.Â  Did the court err in refusing to grant a directed verdict of acquittal to the charge of murder since the evidence raised only a suspicion of his guilt?
1.Â  TESTIMONY RE FRANCHEYâ€™S CHANGE OF DEMEANOR
Weston asserts the testimony of Suzanne Allen and Toni Franchey was improper under this Courtâ€™s opinion in State v. Garcia and under Rule 803(3), SCRE.Â  We disagree.
Suzanne Allen, a friend of Franchey, testified that, during the time period before Weston moved in with her, Franchey was a happy person, cheerful, and fun to be with.Â  When the Solicitor asked Allen what was Francheyâ€™s state of mind concerning Weston, defense counselâ€™s objection pursuant to State v. Garcia, 334 S.C. 71, 512 S.E.2d 507 (1999) was overruled.Â  Allen testified â€œShe was very unhappy.â€Â  The colloquy continued as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q.Â  She was unhappy?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  Very unhappy.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q.Â  Had her demeanor changed as she lived with her son?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  Oh, yes.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q.Â  That summer of 1998, had you given her any advice about her son?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  Yes, I encouraged her to ask him to leave by maybe providing some funds for him to get a place of his own because she seemed so miserable having him live with her. . . . 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . . . . . 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q.Â  Did you have a conversation with Ms. Franchey on that Tuesday?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A. Yes. . . . 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q.Â  Did she tell you that she intended to do something?. . . 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  Yes. . . . she said, Iâ€™m finally going to ask him to leave, I want my home back.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q. . . . Did you ever talk to her after that Tuesday, August the 4th?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  No I did not.
Thereafter, the state called Westonâ€™s sister, Toni Franchey, from whom Weston had been estranged for many years.Â  Toni Franchey was living in Australia at the time of her motherâ€™s disappearance, but had come to Columbia for a family reunion in the summer of 1997.Â  She testified that â€œat that time, I discussed with the family the fact that I became aware that Jeff was planning to move in with my mother and I strongly opposed it.Â  I was afraid.â€ Â Â  Toni Franchey went on to testify about her July 1998 visit at which time she advised her mother that she should find Weston alternate housing.Â  The state queried as follows:
          Q.Â  During that two week period just before your motherâ€™s disappearance, what was her - - I need to be specific.Â  What was her state of mind about Jeff?
          Defense counsel:Â  I object to that.Â  That is not a proper state of mind question.Â  Foundation is not proper and I submit itâ€™s hearsay.
          The court:Â  Overruled.
          A.Â  She was - - she seemedâ€”she seemed more nervous and ---
Defense counsel objected that this was not within the Garcia exception.Â  The court overruled the objection and Toni Franchey continued:
She seemed much more nervous and anxious than normal.Â  My mother is very vivacious, outgoing and loves to, you know, have a laugh and, you know, go out and get something to eat and she just seemed more anxious and just uncertain.Â  I know that while we were doing the house we - she said, well, please donâ€™t touch anything in Jeffâ€™s room and we didnâ€™t because she was afraid.
Weston contends the testimony of Suzanne Allen and Toni Franchey was improper.Â  We disagree.
In Garcia, the defendant was charged with the murder of his girlfriend.Â  He admitted shooting her, but claimed it had been an accident.[5]Â  At trial, Garcia objected to the testimony of two witnesses who testified that the decedent was scared of him.Â  These witnesses were allowed to go further and state that the day before her death, the victim had told her grandmother that Garcia kicked her, causing a bruise below her knee, and that, a week before her death, Garcia had told the victim that if she ever left him, he would kill her.Â  331 S.C. at 73-74, 512 S.E.2d at 508.Â  
We held, â€œthe victimâ€™s state of mind - that she was scared of appellant - was relevant because it -tended to disprove appellantâ€™s contention the shooting was an accident; the victim's fear suggests appellant may have intended the shooting.â€Â  Id. at 74, 512 S.E.2d at 608.Â  We then went on to hold:
Consequently, while the present state of the declarantâ€™s mind is admissible as an exception to hearsay, the reason for the declarant's state of mind is not.Â  United States v. Cohen, 631 F.2d 1223, 1225 (5th Cir.1980) (â€œBut the state-of-mind exception does not permit the witness to relate any of the declarant's statements as to why he held the particular state of mind, or what he might have believed that would have induced the state of mind. If the reservation in the text of the rule is to have any effect, it must be understood to narrowly limit those admissible statements to declarations of conditionâ€”â€˜Iâ€™m scaredâ€™--and not beliefâ€”â€˜Iâ€™m scared because [someone] threatened meâ€™.â€
334 S.C. at 76, 512 S.E.2d at 508 (emphasis supplied).Â  
We find the testimony in the present case was properly admitted under Garcia.Â  The testimony in this case did not give a reason for Mrs. Francheyâ€™s fear.Â  Rather, Toni Franchey and Suzanne Allen testified only that Mrs. Franchey was afraid of Weston.Â  To read Garcia as Weston suggests would require us to hold that a witness may testify to the fact that the decedent was afraid, but not that the decedent was afraid of the defendant.Â  This is simply too constrained a reading of Garcia.Â  We specifically held that â€œthe victimâ€™s state of mind- - that she was scared of appellant- - was relevant. . .â€ 334 S.C. at 74, 512 S.E.2d at 508.Â  Accordingly, the testimony here was clearly admissible under Garcia.
n any event, even had the testimony been improperly admitted, Weston simply cannot demonstrate reversible error.Â  The improper admission of hearsay is reversible error only when the admission causes prejudice.Â  State v. Craig, 267 S.C. 262, 227 S.E.2d 306 (1976); State v. McWee, 322 S.C. 387, 472 S.E.2d 235 (1996), cert. denied, 519 U.S. 1061 (1997) (error without prejudice does not warrant reversal); State v. Mizell, 332 S.C. 273, 504 S.E.2d 338 (Ct. App. 1998) (in order to obtain new trial based upon erroneous admission of evidence, appellant must demonstrate both error and prejudice).Â  
Here, prior to the testimony of either Suzanne Allen or Toni Franchey, the assistant manager of the apartment complex, Leslie Fuller, testified.Â  When asked what was Francheyâ€™s state of mind in reference to her son the weekend of August 7-9, 1998, Fuller testified, without objection, as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  Well, when I saw her she was - she was usually crying and wringing her hands and I would say depressed, anxious.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q.Â  And who was she depressed or anxious about when she would - Were you aware of who she was depressed or anxious about?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  Yeah, she talked with me about it.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q. And who was she depressed or anxious about?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  About Jeff.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q.Â  And that would be her son?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  Yes.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . . . . . . 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q.Â  Did you give her any advice about her son?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  We talked about - - about her having Jeff move out.
Similarly, Claudia Young, the manager for the apartment complex until July 30, 1998, testified as to her observations of Francheyâ€™s demeanor up until her son came to live with her.Â  Concerning the week leading up to Francheyâ€™s disappearance, Young was questioned:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q.Â  And during that time period did you become aware of her state of mind leading up until when you left July the 30th?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  Yes, I was.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q.Â  What was her state of mind in regard to the defendant?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  She did not want him to live there.Â  She was terrified.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q.Â  And she was terrified specifically of whom?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  Her son.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q.Â  And did you ever witness her demonstrating or did she ever do anything in your presence that indicated that?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . . . 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  She cried.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . . 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q.Â  What did you suggest she do?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  I asked her to let me change the locks on her apartment.
Weston did not object to this testimony.[6]
Given the testimony of Fuller and Young, the testimony of Allen and Toni Franchey was merely cumulative such that Weston cannot demonstrate prejudice.Â  State v. Craig, supra (improper admission of hearsay is reversible error only when the admission causes prejudice).Â  
2.Â  WESTONâ€™S ANIMOSITY TOWARD HIS MOTHER
Weston next asserts error in the solicitorâ€™s question to Leslie Fuller as to whether or not Fuller knew of anyone else, other than Francheyâ€™s son, who had any animosity toward Mrs. Franchey, contending this injected the solicitorâ€™s personal opinion into the matter, and was not based upon the evidence.Â  We disagree.Â  
Contrary to Westonâ€™s contention, immediately prior to this question, the solicitor questioned Fuller as to Francheyâ€™s disappearance.Â  Fuller testified she had gone to check on Franchey around 10:00 a.m. on the morning of August 8, 1998, and gotten no answer when she knocked at the door.Â  She continued calling and left a message on Francheyâ€™s answering machine.Â  The following morning, after several phone calls to Francheyâ€™s telephone, Fuller contacted the apartment security officer, Jarvis, and they went and did a walk-through of the apartment.Â  She finally got in touch with Weston at about 4:40 that afternoon and he expressed no concern over his motherâ€™s disappearance, telling her â€œshe met some man and she ran off with him.Â  She left me a note on the coffee table.â€Â  Fuller continued to testify:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  I donâ€™t recall if it was Monday or Tuesday, but one of those days he came back into my office.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Q.Â  And what was his demeanor when he entered your office that Monday or Tuesday?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â Â  He was very disheveled and he was sweating profusely.Â  His eyes were huge.Â  And he just stood over my desk and he said, to begin with, I was really angry with my mother, and now Iâ€™m just scared.â€
Contrary to Westonâ€™s assertion, the above testimony is some evidence of animosity upon which the solicitor properly based her question.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court properly overruled his objection.Â  
3.Â  WESTONâ€™S RESPONSE TO KATHY JARVIS
Weston objects to the testimony of Kathy Jarvis, the Richland County sheriffâ€™s deputy who served as â€œcourtesy officerâ€ for the apartment complex, to the effect that, when questioned about his Motherâ€™s disappearance, Weston â€œwouldnâ€™t answer anything,â€ was â€œtotally unresponsive,â€ and â€œdid not seem concernedâ€ about his mother.Â  
Although Weston now complains Jarvis gave unqualified â€œexpertâ€ testimony, the only objection below was that Jarvis was giving her opinion.Â  Accordingly, this issue is procedurally barred from review because it differs from the objection raised at trial.Â  State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 587 S.E.2d 691 (2003); State v. Prioleau, 345 S.C. 404, 548 S.E.2d 213 (2001); State v. Benton, 338 S.C. 151, 526 S.E.2d 228 (2000) (party may not argue one ground at trial and an alternate ground on appeal).Â  
In any event, Jarvis was simply relaying her personal experience in law enforcement and the fact that she had not encountered anyone so unresponsive.Â  We find no basis for objection.Â  State v. McClinton, 265 S.C. 171, 217 S.E.2d 584 (1975) (witness may state his impression or inference with respect to the appearance of a person, animal, object, or place if he has had adequate opportunity for observation, the details of such appearance cannot be reproduced before the jury to enable them to draw a correct inference, and he states as much as possible of the constituent facts).Â  
4.Â  WESTONâ€™S STATEMENT AT STORAGE UNIT
Weston moved out of his motherâ€™s apartment the weekend of August 21, 1998, and moved into an apartment on Confederate Avenue, owned by his friend, Francis Perna.Â  Perna helped Weston move into the apartment, retrieving Westonâ€™s personal belongings both from the apartment in Harbison, and from a Public Storage Unit on Broad River Road.Â  When they arrived at the storage unit, they found a search warrant.Â  Weston read the search warrant and said, â€œI need a lawyer.â€Â  
Weston asserts the trial court erred in allowing Perna to comment that he stated â€œI need a lawyer.â€ Â He contends this was an improper comment on his right to an attorney and that, in any event, it was impermissible under Rule 403, SCRE, as its prejudice outweighed its probative value.Â  We disagree and find Weston has not shown reversible error from admission of this single comment. 
In Doyle v. Ohio, 426 U.S. 610 (1976), the United States Supreme Court held that the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment is violated when a state prosecutor seeks to impeach a defendantâ€™s exculpatory story, told for the first time at the trial, by cross-examining him about his post-arrest silence after receiving Miranda warnings.Â  Doyle also prohibits the State from commenting upon the defendantâ€™s request for an attorney. See Wainwright v. Greenfield, 474 U.S. 284 (1986); Edmond v. State, 341 S.C. 340, 345, 534 S.E.2d 682, 685 (2000).Â  The rationale for Doyle is that it would be a violation of due process to allow comment on the silence which Miranda warnings have encouraged.Â  
Subsequent to Doyle, inÂ  Fletcher v. Weir, 455 U.S. 603 (1982), the Supreme Court clarified that Doyle was applicable only in situations in which the government had induced, via Miranda warnings, a defendantâ€™s belief that his exercise of a constitutional right would not be used against him.Â  455 U.S. at 607 (â€œin the absence of the sort of affirmative assurances embodied in the Miranda warnings, we do not believe that it violates due process of law for a State to permit cross-examination as to post arrest silence when a defendant chooses to take the stand.â€Â  See also State v. Bell, 347 S.C. 267, 554 S.E.2d 435 (Ct. App. 2001) (recognizing that Doyle is applicable only after Miranda warnings have been given).Â Â  
 Doyle is simply inapplicable here.Â  Unlike Doyle, Weston was not under arrest at the time he told Perna that he needed a lawyer, nor had he been given Miranda warnings by authorities.Â  Under Fletcher, it is clear Doyle is inapplicable to Westonâ€™s statement to his friend.Â  Accord State v. Baccam, 476 N.W.2d 884, 886 (Iowa Ct.App.1991).
5.Â  DIRECTED VERDICT
Lastly, Weston contends the trial court erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict, claiming the state failed to prove the corpus delicti of a murder and that there was no evidence he caused Mrs. Francheyâ€™s death.Â  We disagree and find the matter was properly submitted to the jury.Â  
When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight.Â  A defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the state fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.Â  When reviewing a denial of a directed verdict, this Court views the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the state.Â  If there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, the Court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 593-593, 606 S.E.2d 475, 477-478 (2004).Â  See also State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 653, 572 S.E.2d 267, 273 (2002); State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 555, 564 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2002); State v. Venters, 300 S.C. 260, 264, 387 S.E.2d 270, 272-73 (1990). 
In a murder case, the corpus delicti consists of two elements: the death of a human being, and the criminal act of another in causing that death. State v. Martin, 47 S.C. 67, 25 S.E. 113 (1896).Â  In State v. Owens, 293 S.C. 161, 359 S.E.2d 275 (1987), this Court held that the circumstantial evidence surrounding the victimâ€™s sudden disappearance, considered with the unlikelihood of his voluntary departure as shown by his personal habits and relationships, was sufficient to establish the corpus delicti of murder or that the victim is dead by the criminal act of another. Â See State v. Speights, 263 S.C. 127, 208 S.E.2d 43 (1974).Â  See also State v. Copeland, 321 S.C. 318, 468 S.E.2d 620 (1996).Â  
Here, the state presented evidence that Mrs. Franchey had an active social life, was active with friends, at bridge club, and regularly kept in touch with the apartment complex managers, her sister, and her friends.Â  She was last seen on August 6, 1998, via a bank video camera, making a withdrawal from her bank account.Â  She has not been seen nor heard from since.Â  Under Owens, the stateâ€™s presentation of the victimâ€™s habits, coupled with her mysterious disappearance, and the fact that she has not been seen nor heard from since August 1998, are sufficient to establish the corpus delicti of murder.
Further, the evidence presented by the state warranted submission of the case to the jury.Â  Evidence was presented that Weston had gone to live with his mother in the fall of 1997, and that she became very upset and was depressed Weston was living with her.Â  Friends and family advised Franchey to either change the locks, eject Weston, or find him another place to live.Â  Two days before her disappearance, Franchey told a friend she had decided to tell Weston to leave.Â  She was last seen alive on August 6, 1998.Â  The same day, the maintenance supervisor of the apartment complex noticed that the trunk to Mrs. Francheyâ€™s vehicle was open, and was lined with clear plastic.Â  The maintenance supervisor also testified that Franchey, a retired educator, did not have any bumper stickers on her car but that, immediately after she disappeared, a sticker which read â€œMy kid beat up your honor roll studentâ€ was on the car.Â Â  The apartment manager testified that when she went to the apartment on Aug. 8th, the shower curtain in Francheyâ€™s bathroom was missing.
Randy Myers, an apartment complex resident, testified that at 4:30 a.m. on Saturday, August 8th, he saw Weston loading garbage bags into the trunk of Francheyâ€™s car.Â  Several people also testified that they had never seen Weston drive Francheyâ€™s car before, Weston did not have a driverâ€™s license, and that immediately after Franchey disappeared, Weston was driving her car.Â  
The apartment complex manager testified that, when she went to check on Franchey, she saw that Francheyâ€™s plants on her back patio were turned over, and there was an empty bleach bottle on the porch.Â  When initially confronted by the apartment complex manager and Officer Jarvis, Weston told them his mother had â€œmet some man and run off with himâ€ leaving him a note on the coffee table.Â  No other witness had any knowledge of an alleged boyfriend.Â  Further, although the apartment complex manager and Jarvis remembered seeing Francheyâ€™s purse and glasses on her bed in the apartment on August 8th, Weston told police that his motherâ€™s purse was missing.Â Â  The apartment complex manager also testified that Weston came into her office a day or two later, very disheveled, sweating profusely, his eyes huge, and stated, â€œI was really angry with my mother and now Iâ€™m just scared.â€Â  
Immediately after Francheyâ€™s disappearance, Weston called in sick to his job at Target for two days, saying he had a virus.Â  He returned to work on Monday, August 10th, and was seen by employees to have a limp, a bruise under his eye, and scratches on his arms.Â Â  He told his supervisor his cat had scratched him.Â  He told another co-worker he had stepped off a curb and fallen into some bushes.Â  When Jarvis and the apartment manager spoke to Weston at Francheyâ€™s apartment, Weston was wearing a heavy black jacket on a hot August day such that his arms were not visible.Â  When Weston went back to work at Target, he bought a new shower curtain, and a rug.Â  When police investigated the apartment, they found an area rug covering a hole in the carpet of the living room floor.Â  Linoleum in the kitchen floor had also been torn up and was missing.Â  Police tested the floor where the linoleum had been removed and found blood; blood was also found on drag marks leading from the hole in the carpet.Â  Investigators subsequently tested a piece of blood-stained molding from the apartment which was determined to be was Francheyâ€™s.Â  Blood was also found on the rubber ring that lined the trunk of Francheyâ€™s car.Â  
The above evidence, although circumstantial, is clearly sufficient to withstand a motion for a directed verdict.Â  Â The judgment below is affirmed.
 AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., BURNETT, PLEICONES, J.J., and Acting Justice Stephen S. Bartlett concur.

[1]Â  There was also testimony that Weston called in sick from his job at Target on Thurs. and Friday, August 6th and 7th, telling his supervisor he had a stomach virus.Â  
[2] Â Westonâ€™s sister, Toni Franchey, testified that her mother did not allow him to drive the car as he did not have a driverâ€™s license.Â  
[3] Â No other witness had ever seen Franchey in the company of a boyfriend.
[4] Â Weston had purchased a shower curtain and an area rug from his job at Target during the week of August 10-14th.Â  
[5] Â As here, the defendant in Garcia offered no evidence at trial.
[6] Â Although Weston did object to the proper foundation,Â  no further objection is contained in the record.
