title: David v. McLeod Regional Medical Center
description: Willie Mae David appealed the trial courtâ€™s decision granting the respondentsâ€™ motions for summary judgment.  As in the previous opinion, this Court affirms the trial courtâ€™s decision.  The original opinion is withdrawn and substituted with this opinion.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Willie May David and J.D. David, Appellants,
v.
McLeod Regional Medical Center, Dr. Ken Brusett, Individually, Pee Dee Cardiovascular Surgeons, Pee Dee Pathology, and Dr. H. K. Habermeier, Individually, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Florence County
Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26020Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Heard February 1, 2005 - Refiled January 23, 2006Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Eduardo K. Curry and Carl B. Grant, both of Curry & Counts, of Charleston; and Jayne G. Helm, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellants.
J. Rene Josey, of Turner Padget Graham & Laney, of Florence; Mark W. Buyck, Jr.,Â  of Wilcox Buyck & Williams, of Florence; and Robert H. Hood, D. Nathan Hughey, and Deborah H. Sheffield, all of Hood Law Firm, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Willie Mae David (Appellant), the plaintiff in the underlying medical malpractice action, appeals the trial courtâ€™s decision granting the respondentsâ€™ motions for summary judgment.Â  This case was certified from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  We withdraw our original opinion in this matter and substitute it with this opinion affirming the trial courtâ€™s decision.Â  
Factual /Procedural Background
Appellant underwent surgery after her family doctor found a lesion on Appellantâ€™s lower left lung.Â  Specifically, Appellant underwent a â€œwedge biopsy,â€ where a thoracic surgeon extracted a portion of the suspicious tissue and sent the tissue to a pathologist for diagnosis.Â  The pathologist returned a preliminary diagnosis of â€œprobable pulmonary blastoma,â€ a rare form of cancer, which was confirmed by the pathologistâ€™s partner.Â  Based on this diagnosis, the thoracic surgeon decided to remove the lower left portion of Appellantâ€™s lung while Appellant was still anesthetized and unconscious.
A final pathology report, issued three days after the surgery, concluded that the lesion was not cancerous, but rather, a â€œpulmonary endometrioma;â€ a rare form of endometriosis, which, from a visual inspection, closely resembles pulmonary blastoma.[1]Â  
Appellant filed the underlying action and named the following parties as defendants: (1) the hospital where the surgery took place (McLeod Regional), (2) the thoracic surgeon who performed the surgery (Dr. Brusett), (3) Dr. Brusettâ€™s practice group (Pee Dee Cardiovascular Surgeons), (4) the pathologist who provided the preliminary diagnosis (Dr. Habermeier), and (5) Dr. Habermeierâ€™s practice group (Pee Dee Pathology).Â  Appellant claimed that she suffers from several ailments as a result of the surgery, including chest and back pain, shortness of breath, and anxiety.
Respondents filed separate motions for summary judgment.[2] Â McLeod Regional sought summary judgment on the grounds that any alleged malpractice was performed by independent contractors; therefore, the hospital could not be vicariously liable for Appellantâ€™s alleged injuries.Â  The remaining Respondents sought summary judgment arguing that Appellant had failed to establish the essential elements of her case; specifically, that Appellant had failed to produce expert testimony establishing the applicable standard of care, breach of that standard, and a causal connection between the breach and Appellantâ€™s injuries.Â  The trial court granted the Respondentsâ€™ motions for summary judgment in three separate orders.Â  Appellant now raises the following issues for review: 

  
    
      
        I.
        Did the trial court err in granting the respondent physiciansâ€™ motions for summary judgment?
        
      
      
        II.
         Did the trial court err in holding that McLeod Regional was not vicariously liable for Appellantâ€™s alleged damages?
        
      
    
  

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Respondent Physiciansâ€™ Motions for Summary Judgment
Appellant argues that the trial court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of the respondent physicians.Â  We disagree.
When reviewing an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard as the trial court. Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002). Summary judgment is appropriate when there is no genuine issue of material fact such that the moving party must prevail as a matter of law.  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences that may be drawn from the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.  Fleming, 350 S.C. at 493-94, 567 S.E.2d at 860.
As the trial court recognized, the rules of civil procedure describe what an affidavit must contain in order to establish an issue of fact sufficient to defeat a motion for summary judgment.Â  Rule 56(e), SCRCP provides that â€œ[s]upporting and opposing affidavits shall be made on personal knowledge, shall set forth such facts as would be admissible in evidence, and shall show affirmatively that the affiant is competent to testify as to the matters stated therein.â€
A physician commits malpractice by not exercising that degree of skill and learning that is ordinarily possessed and exercised by members of the profession in good standing acting in the same or similar circumstances.Â  Durham v. Vinson, 360 S.C. 639, 650-51, 62 S.E.2d 760, 766 (2004).Â  Additionally, medical malpractice lawsuits have specific requirements that must be satisfied in order for a genuine factual issue to exist.Â  Specifically, a plaintiff alleging medical malpractice must provide evidence showing (1) the generally recognized and accepted practices and procedures that would be followed by average, competent practitioners in the defendantsâ€™ field of medicine under the same or similar circumstances, and (2) that the defendants departed from the recognized and generally accepted standards.Â  Pederson v. Gould, 288 S.C. 141, 143-44, 341 S.E.2d 633, 634 (1986); Cox v. Lund, 286 S.C. 410, 414, 334 S.E.2d 116, 118 (1985).Â  Â Â Also, the plaintiff must show that the defendantsâ€™ departure from such generally recognized practices and procedures was the proximate cause of the plaintiffâ€™s alleged injuries and damages.Â  Green v. Lilliewood, 272 S.C. 186, 193, 249 S.E.2d 910, 913 (1978).Â  The plaintiff must provide expert testimony to establish both the required standard of care and the defendantsâ€™ failure to conform to that standard, unless the subject matter lies within the ambit of common knowledge so that no special learning is required to evaluate the conduct of the defendants.Â  Pederson, 288 S.C. at 143, 341 S.E.2d at 634.Â  Therefore, in order to withstand a properly supported motion for summary judgment in a medical malpractice action, any affidavits presented to the court must first comply with the terms of Rule 56, SCRCP, and the evidence as a whole must meet the criteria laid out in Pederson and its progeny.
In the present case, Appellant relies solely on the affidavit of pathologist Dr. Brian Frist to create a genuine issue of material fact as to the commission of malpractice by the respondent physicians.[3]Â  The trial court ruled that Dr. Fristâ€™s affidavit failed to establish that he is familiar with the standard of care from which the respondent physicians allegedly deviated.Â Â  We agree and find that the affidavit is insufficient.
In his affidavit, Dr. Fristâ€™s sole opinion as to Dr. Brusettâ€™s alleged malpractice is that Dr. Brusett failed â€œto make sure that he communicated to the pathologist his thoughts for treatment, so that the pathologist was aware of the treatment plan of the surgeon.â€Â  First, Dr. Frist incorrectly relies on the assumption that the pathologist would have diagnosed Appellantâ€™s tumor differently had Dr. Brusett â€œcommunicated his thoughts for treatmentâ€ before Appellantâ€™s tumor was tested.Â  Stated differently, Dr. Fristâ€™s affidavit fails to explain how Dr. Brusettâ€™s post-diagnosis treatment would have affected the pathologistâ€™s initial diagnosis of the tumor.Â Â  As a result, there is no evidence that Dr. Brusettâ€™s failure to communicate Appellantâ€™s possible treatment options with the pathologist was the proximate cause of Appellantâ€™s injuries.Â  
The dissent asserts that had the pathologist been aware that Dr. Brusett intended to immediately remove the affected portion of the lung upon a diagnosis of pulmonary blastoma, then the pathologist might have qualified or sought to confirm his preliminary diagnosis.Â  The dissentâ€™s argument disregards the necessity that a surgeon be able to rely upon inter-operative diagnoses to determine a patientâ€™s proper treatment.Â  Moreover, the position argued by the dissent would set the precedent that a speculative hypothetical may serve as the standard of care in an action for medical malpractice.Â  In South Carolina, medical malpractice actions require a greater showing than generic allegations and conjecture.Â  
Second, Appellant provides no evidence that her expert, Dr. Frist, is familiar with the standard of care that Dr. Brusett or Dr. Habermeier allegedly breached, nor does Appellant offer what the applicable standard of care might be.Â  Nothing in Dr. Fristâ€™s affidavit, or in the record, suggests it was unreasonable for Dr. Brusett to extract the lesion after receiving a diagnosis of â€œprobable pulmonary blastoma,â€ and nothing in Dr. Fristâ€™s affidavit, or in the record, instructs the Court with any specificity as to how competent practitioners in these fields would have performed this procedure differently.Â  
We are mindful of the important interests at stake in this case.Â  People who receive sub-standard medical care must be able to recover for injuries caused by at-fault physicians, and Plaintiffs must have a meaningful opportunity to present and support their claims in court.Â  However, all of the evidence in this case suggests that Appellant received competent medical care.Â  This is a case where a thoracic surgeon removed a piece of suspicious tissue, a pathologist and his partner returned a preliminary diagnosis of rare cancer, and the surgeon decided to take the tissue out.Â  In support of her claim, Appellant offers an expertâ€™s affidavits saying â€œyou should have communicated better and you got the diagnosis wrong.â€Â  The affidavits do not establish how the facts of this case would be different had the surgeon and pathologist â€œcommunicated better,â€ nor do they address the standard of care in any detail. 
In affirming the trial court, we rely solely on the requirements of Rule 56, SCRCP, and the specific requirements for expert testimony in medical malpractice actions.Â  A doctor need not practice in the particular area of medicine as the defendant doctor to be qualified to testify as an expert.Â  Creed v. City of Columbia, 310 S.C. 342, 345, 426 S.E.2d 785, 786. (1993).Â  Regardless of the area in which the prospective expert witness practices, he must set forth the applicable standard of care for the medical procedure under scrutiny and he must demonstrate to the court that he is familiar with the standard of care.Â  A court considering summary judgment neither makes factual determinations nor considers the merits of competing testimony; however, summary judgment is completely appropriate when a properly supported motion sets forth facts that remain undisputed or are contested in a deficient manner.Â  Despite Dr. Fristâ€™s qualifications, his affidavit does not set forth the standard of care he alleges was breached, nor does it provide that he is familiar the standard of care.Â  Therefore, we hold that the trial court did not err in granting summary judgment in favor of Respondents Brusett, Pee Dee Cardiovascular, Habermeier and Pee Dee Pathology.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Vicarious Liability of McLeod Regional 
Appellant argues that McLeod Regional had a nondelegable duty to provide competent pathology care to Appellant and therefore was vicariously liable for Dr. Habermeierâ€™s preliminary misdiagnosis that resulted in unnecessary surgery.Â  Because we hold that the trial court properly granted summary judgment in favor of Dr. Habermeier and Pee Dee Pathology, we need not address this issue.Â  See Rookland v. Atlanta & C. Air Line Ry. Co., 84 S.C. 190, 192, 65 S.E. 1047, 1049 (1909) (judgment on the merits in favor of the agent bars a vicarious liability action against the principal).Â  
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision granting the respondentsâ€™ motions for summary judgment.
MOORE, J. and Acting Justice Paula H. Thomas concur. PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which BURNETT, J., concurs.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent from the majorityâ€™s decision to affirm the grant of summary judgment to the Respondent doctors and their practices, but join the decision to affirm the grant to Respondent McLeod. As explained below, I find Dr. Fristâ€™s affidavit adequate to create a genuine issue of material fact whether the communication between the surgeon and the pathologist fell below generally accepted standards and procedures.[4]
Â As I understand Dr. Fristâ€™s affidavit, the assertion is that if Dr. Brusett had informed the pathologist that he intended to immediately remove the affected portion of the lung if the intra-operative diagnosis were cancer, then Dr. Habermeier might have qualified his preliminary diagnosis. Contrary to the majorityâ€™s characterization of the affidavit, it does not assume that Dr. Habermeierâ€™s diagnosis would have been different, but rather opines that had Dr. Habermeier been aware of Dr. Brusettâ€™s intentions, Dr. Habermeier would have properly communicated â€œhis pathological diagnosis and thoughts, to the rareness of his findings, so that the diagnosis could be used for the proper treatment of the patient at that moment.â€
The majority holds that there is nothing in the affidavit to suggest that it was unreasonable for Dr. Brusett to have removed part of the lung upon receiving the blastoma diagnosis.Â  I do not disagree; however, as I understand the Appellantsâ€™ theory, they allege a deviation from the standard of care in the communications between the surgeon and the pathologist, not in the surgical decision made upon receipt of the pathology report.Â  In my opinion, the reasonableness of Dr. Brusettâ€™s decision is not relevant to the summary judgment motion.
The majority also affirms, without discussion, the trial courtâ€™s holding that Dr. Fristâ€™s affidavit failed to establish his familiarity with the standard of care.Â  I would hold that Dr. Fristâ€™s affidavit indicating proficiency in the specialty involved, coupled with the statement â€œ It is my opinion, to a reasonable degree of medical certainty, that each of these Defendants deviated from the acceptable standard of care and were negligent . . . in the following particulars . . . .â€ is sufficient to establish that he is familiar with the standard of care. 
In my opinion, the trial court erred in holding that Dr. Fristâ€™s affidavit did not demonstrate the existence of a genuine issue of material fact whether one or both physicians committed malpractice in failing to adequately communicate before and during the biopsy.Â  See, e.g., Helena Chem. Co. v. Allianz Underwriters Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 631, 594 S.E.2d 455 (2004) (summary judgment is drastic remedy that should be cautiously invoked).Â  I would therefore reverse the orders granting Respondents Brusett and Habermeier and their groups summary judgment.Â  I would affirm the grant of summary judgment to McLeod, however, because there is simply no evidence in this record that the Appellants looked to the hospital rather than to the individual doctors for Mrs. Davisâ€™s care.Â  Osborne v. McLeod Reg. Med. Center, 346 S.C. 4, 550 S.E.2d 319 (2001) (in order to hold hospital vicariously liable for staff negligence, plaintiff must present evidence that she looked to the hospital for care).
BURNETT, J., concurs.

[1] The evidence in this case suggests that the tissue removed for diagnosis unfortunately proved difficult to analyze.Â  The sample was so strange that after determining that the tissue was not cancerous, the pathologist sent the sample to the Department of Defense, who replied â€œ[w]hile the endometroid glandular architecture would cause one to consider the possibility of pulmonary blastoma, the histology is completely compatible with a diagnosis of endometriomaâ€¦[t]hank you for sending this interesting case.â€Â  
[2] Specifically, Respondents filed three motions for summary judgment: (1) McLeod Regional, (2) Dr. Brusett and Pee Dee Cardiovascular Surgeons, and (3) Dr. Habermeier and Pee Dee Pathology.Â  The Respondentsâ€™ briefs to this Court were submitted in this fashion as well.
[3] Initially, Appellant named only one expert in her response to interrogatories:Â  Dr. Hossein Tirgan, an oncologist in the state of New Jersey.Â  Dr. Tirgan, by way of affidavit and deposition, opined that all Respondents were negligent in some manner. The trial court found that Dr. Tirgan was not qualified to render an expert opinion in this case, and Appellant did not appeal that ruling.Â  
Appellant named Dr. Frist as an expert only two days before the summary judgment hearing.Â  Respondents had no opportunity to depose Dr. Frist.Â  As a result, the only evidence that the trial court had to consider was Dr. Fristâ€™s affidavit.Â  Therefore, we focus solely on Dr. Fristâ€™s affidavit to determine whether summary judgment was proper.
[4] I note with concern that the majority opinion could be read to import the medical malpractice plaintiffâ€™s evidentiary burden at trial into the summary judgment standard. Durham v. Vinson, Pederson v. Gould, Cox v, Lund, and Green v. Lilliewood are all appeals from cases that went to trial, and which decide whether the plaintiff had met her burden at that proceeding.Â  A motion for summary judgment is not a mini-trial, requiring the medical malpractice plaintiff to present evidence meeting her trial burden.Â  We are concerned here with the sufficiency of Dr. Fristâ€™s affidavit, and not with whether â€œthe evidence as a whole [meets] the criteria laid out in PedersonÂ  and its progeny [sic].â€Â  See Schulz v. Esposito, 210 A.D.2d 307, 308, 619 N.Y.S.2d 744, 775 (1994)(â€œIssue finding rather than issue determination is the key [to summary judgment]â€).

title: In the Matter of Newberry County Magistrate Mark E. English
description: This is an opinion in which the Court publicly reprimands a magistrate.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Newberry County Magistrate Mark E. English,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26100
Submitted January 4, 2006 - Filed January 23, 2006

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
Mark E. English, of Newberry, pro se.Â Â Â Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this judicial disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of an admonition, public reprimand, or a definite suspension for thirty (30) days pursuant to Rule 7(b), RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  The facts as set forth in the agreement are as follows.Â  
FACTS
At the time of the submission of the agreement and, on the occasion of the occurrences discussed hereafter, respondent was a Newberry County magistrate.Â  Respondent has since tendered his resignation as a Newberry County Magistrate effective at midnight on December 31, 2005.Â  
Matter I
For quite some time and long prior to respondentâ€™s magisterial appointment, it was standard practice in the Newberry County Magistrateâ€™s Court for a representative of the Sheriffâ€™s Department to appear at bench trials in criminal cases in lieu of the appearance of the arresting officer and/or complaining witness(es) and to have the Sheriffâ€™s Department representative (who had no first hand knowledge of the case) testify for the State by reading the information from the incident report.Â  If the defendant contested the charge, the case would be continued until the arresting officer and/or the complaining witness(es) could be present.[1]Â  Respondent represents he followed the procedure described above as it was used by his predecessors and other Newberry County magistrates.Â  
After discussing the Newberry County Magistrate Courtâ€™s procedure and related legal principles with ODC, respondent now recognizes that the Magistrateâ€™s Court was, in effect, depriving pro se defendants of the constitutionally guaranteed right to confront their accusers.Â  Respondent warrants that, in the future, he will cease allowing defendants to plead guilty or be convicted solely on the basis of incident reports.
ODC does not contend that it is judicial misconduct for a judge to allow hearsay testimony into a proceeding where there is no objection, even in cases where a defendant is pro se, but, instead, contends that fundamental principles of jurisprudence require some admissible evidence of the commission of a crime as a prerequisite to proceeding with a criminal case.Â  In addition, ODC contends Magistrateâ€™s Court should not accommodate the prosecution and deprive pro se defendants of basic constitutional rights.Â  
The Court emphasizes that while a criminal defendant may plead guilty without any evidence of his guilt being submitted, a defendant who pleads not guilty cannot be convicted solely on the basis of a police incident report.Â  The burden is on the government to prove a defendantâ€™s guilt beyond a reasonable doubt based on competent evidence.Â  
Matter II
Respondent terminated an employee due to her being unable to satisfactorily perform her duties as a result of personal, domestic difficulties.Â  After notice of termination, respondent continued to pay the employee for several weeks for â€œaccumulated sick leaveâ€ even though no evidence of illness was presented to respondent.Â  Respondent signed or caused to be signed the employeeâ€™s name to a time sheet submitted for payment of the sick leave.Â  The actual document from respondent to Newberry County memorializing the termination was not transmitted until the sick leave had been exhausted. 
Respondent now recognizes that the right to sick leave did not continue after the employeeâ€™s termination, particularly in the absence of medical documentation supporting illness and that, at a minimum, he should have printed the employeeâ€™s name, not had it signed in cursive to indicate the former employee had signed the document.[2]Â  Respondent recognizes that the signing of another personâ€™s name in cursive to a time sheet and paying sick leave to a terminated employee who might or might not have been sick constituted judicial misconduct.[3]Â  
Matter III
Respondent loaned a motor vehicle to the same employee mentioned above while she was an employee of the Newberry County Central System.[4]Â  While driving the vehicle, the employee was involved in a motor vehicle accident and was issued a traffic citation by a South Carolina Highway Patrol trooper.Â  The citation charged her with driving too fast for conditions.Â  
Respondent asked the charging trooper if he could â€œhelpâ€ the employee with the ticket as respondent believed the fine should have been suspended due to the fact that the employee was â€œa court employee who assisted troopers daily.â€ According to respondent, the charging trooper indicated he was unwilling to â€œhelpâ€ the employee with the ticket at that juncture because of the high visibility of the case, the known relationship between respondent and the employee,[5] existing animosity between respondent and another Newberry County Magistrate, Magistrate Beckham, and the fact that the motor vehicle the employee was driving was owned by respondent.Â  The trooper offered to continue the matter and revisit its disposition if circumstances made doing so less subject to criticism.[6]Â  The employee paid the fine marked on the ticket and respondent â€œsigned offâ€ on the ticket, causing it to be processed in a routine fashion.Â  
Respondent now recognizes it was judicial misconduct to have had an ex parte communication with the charging trooper and to even suggest the trooper â€œhelpâ€ the employee.Â  Respondent further recognizes that employees of the judicial system or law enforcement are not any more entitled to â€œhelpâ€ by virtue of their positions than other defendants and should, instead, be treated the same as any other person charged with an offense.Â  Â 
Matter IV
Respondent received a traffic citation for driving too fast for conditions.Â  The ticket was issued by a South Carolina Highway Patrol trooper as a result of a motor vehicle accident.Â  The ticket was returnable before Magistrate Rushton.Â  Respondent felt he was not at fault and planned to contest the ticket.Â  
When the case was called to be heard before Magistrate Rushton, respondent entered a plea of not guilty.Â  No witness appeared and the trooper announced that he did not wish to proceed with the prosecution without witnesses present since he did not witness the accident.Â  Magistrate Rushton ruled the matter should be dismissed and/or found respondent not guilty on the date of trial.Â Â  
Magistrate Rushton â€œsigned offâ€ so as to indicate â€œdismissedâ€ or â€œnot guiltyâ€ on the copy of the ticket sent to the South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) and on the trooperâ€™s copy of the ticket.Â  However, the court record copy of the ticket could not be located until several months after Magistrate Rushton had ceased being a magistrate. 
Respondent felt it was necessary to cause the court records to conform to the DMV records.Â  For that reason, respondent telephoned Magistrate Rushton and Magistrate Rushton authorized that his name be â€œsigned offâ€ on the courtâ€™s copy of the ticket.Â  Respondent then instructed the employee mentioned above to sign Magistrate Rushtonâ€™s name on the ticket showing it as â€œnot guiltyâ€ and/or â€œdismissedâ€ (as it should have originally been marked by Magistrate Rushton had it been available on the trial date).Â  However, Magistrate Rushton was not present when the court copy of the ticket was signed and, in fact, was no longer a magistrate on that occasion. 
Respondent now recognizes it was judicial misconduct to authorize the employee to sign Magistrate Rushtonâ€™s name (even with his permission and only to conform to the actual disposition of the ticket) because a directive from the Chief Justice concerning the â€œsigning offâ€ of tickets only allows court employees to sign a judgeâ€™s name on traffic tickets in the judgeâ€™s presence.Â  Respondent recognizes the correct procedure would have been to have Magistrate Ruston sign the court copy nunc pro tunc or, at least, mark it â€œs/Rushton [printed]â€ indicating it was being conformed to the original, rather than suggesting Magistrate Rushton had actually signed the ticket or that someone with his authority had signed it in his presence while he was a judge.Â  Respondent now recognizes that, with very few exceptions, no one can sign a judgeâ€™s name to legal documents. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Moreover, the employee dated the court copy of the ticket as of the date of the trial (which would have been the date on the DMV and trooperâ€™s copies of the ticket).Â  Respondent explains that the trial date is generally used by Newberry County magistrates when they â€œsign offâ€ a ticket, regardless of the date on which the ticket is actually â€œsigned off.â€Â  ODC does not contest respondentâ€™s representation in this regard but provides the better practice would have been to place the notation â€œSee reverseâ€ by Magistrate Rushtonâ€™s printed name and place an explanation and the actual â€œsign offâ€ date on the reverse of the ticket.Â  
ODC acknowledges respondent gained no advantage as a result of this matter.Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
Matter V
A defendant was charged with driving under the influence.Â  The defendant hired an attorney who filed a written request for a jury trial.Â  The writing was placed in the courtâ€™s case file.Â  Notwithstanding the appearance of the attorney, the matter was scheduled for trial, but the attorney was not notified.Â  
The arresting officer, the defendant, and defense attorney were not present when the case was called for trial.Â  Respondent directed the officer be located.Â  The trial was delayed and the officer was given the opportunity to appear.Â  The officer advised respondent he was not in court when the case was called for trial because he had not been notified of the trial date.Â  No similar effort was made to locate the defendant or to give the defendant an opportunity to be present.Â  The defendant was convicted in his absence.Â  In a later meeting with the defense attorney and the arresting officer it was determined that the defense attorney had not been notified of the trial and respondent, on motion of the defense attorney with consent of the arresting officer, reopened the matter. 
Respondent now recognizes that any disparate treatment afforded the State and the accused gives an appearance of impropriety and suggests a bias towards the State.Â  In the future, respondent represents he will be make equal effort to locate absent defendants and absent law enforcement officers.Â  In addition, he represents he will be more careful to determine whether or not defendants are represented by counsel and, if so, give notice to counsel of upcoming proceedings.Â  
Matter VI
A vending machine is operated in the lobby of the Newberry County Central Court for use by employees and the public.Â  The machine is under respondentâ€™s supervision. The profits from the vending machine are applied to a canteen fund and used for miscellaneous office expenses such as flowers for employees who are sick or suffer losses of loved ones and social events to promote camaraderie among the staff at the Central Court.Â  
While this is a fairly minor matter, ODC contends the practice is contrary to the general laws of the State which require that all income from the State and its political subdivisions be paid over to the county treasurer and that the only expenditures that may be made by public officials are those authorized in an annual budget approved by the governing body of the jurisdiction.Â  In addition, ODC contends use of the vending machine proceeds is contrary to the spirit, if not the letter, of prohibitions in published cases of the Supreme Court of South Carolina and subsequent memorandums of the Chief Justice relating to judges using their position to collect money.Â  
Respondent explains it is a common practice for the various departments of Newberry County to use vending machine profits for similar purposes and that no objection had been raised by any officials of the county prior to the complaint here. Â ODC does not dispute respondentâ€™s representation and concedes the infraction is well intended and follows a general practice in the various departments in Newberry County and possibly across the State.Â  Nevertheless, ODC contends it is contrary to the statutory laws of this State. Â Respondent does not dispute this contention.Â  
Matter VII
When defendants failed to appear for traffic court and did not post bond, respondent would try the defendants in their absence, issue bench warrants, and send the NRVC notice to the DMV.[7]Â  In addition, respondent would either draw or cause to be drawn warrants charging the defendants with violation of South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 56-25-40 (1991) and then have a Sheriffâ€™s Department deputy sign a supporting affidavit.Â  
ODC agrees that the failure to post bond or appear on the date of trial does, in fact, constitute a violation of Section 56-25-40 but contends it is the duty of law enforcement or prosecutors to seek the issuance of warrants, not judges.Â  ODC contends judges should only issue warrants when approached by victims, law enforcement, or prosecutors presenting sufficient evidence for the issuance of warrants.Â Â  
Respondent now recognizes that, except in the case of contempt of court, it is judicial misconduct for a judge to initiate criminal charges.Â  However, in mitigation, respondent represents the practice of issuing warrants was initiated at the request of the Newberry County Sheriffâ€™s Department and that, prior to issuing these warrants, an employee of Court Administration advised him that he could issue warrants under these circumstances.Â  Respondent asserts he issued only a few such warrants and immediately ceased the practice upon receipt of a complaint regarding the matter. 
ODC does not dispute respondentâ€™s representations.Â  The Court Administration employee confirms respondentâ€™s representation but states he did not intend to suggest warrants should be issued sua sponte.Â  ODC contends magistrates should not draw warrants sua sponte and then seek to have a law enforcement officer sign the warrant affidavit.Â  Instead, ODC asserts such warrants should be issued when an affiant with knowledge of a case appears before a judge seeking a warrant for the offense and gives an affidavit setting out probable cause.Â  
Matter VIII
Respondentâ€™s friend was charged with having an expired license tag on his motor vehicle. The friend did not appear at trial, but the records of the proceedings were marked â€œsuspend fine as per [respondent].â€ 
Â Respondent does not recall the exact details of this event; however, he represents that such a disposition was typical as Newberry County Magistrates suspended fines after defendants demonstrated that they had acquired license tags.Â  Respondent states this procedure is fair since citizens often have problems obtaining tags from DMV in a timely fashion.Â  Nevertheless, respondent acknowledges that, since his friend did not appear for trial, he either received information about his friend obtaining his license tag in an ex parte fashion or suspended the fine without knowing for certain that the tag had been obtained.Â  
Matter IX
Respondent released approximately nine (9) prisoners from the Newberry County Detention Center without any legal basis for doing so except for his own decision that this was necessary.Â  These prisoners were serving sentences, many of which were imposed by other judges, including one serving a sentence imposed by a family court judge.Â  Respondent represents he released these prisoners at the request of law enforcement because the detention center was being renovated and the adjoining county could not accommodate all the prisoners incarcerated at the Newberry County Detention Center.Â  Respondent further represents he reviewed each of the prisonerâ€™s sentences and released those with the shortest sentences remaining and only those he felt were non-violent.Â  
ODC does not contest respondentâ€™s representations concerning this matter and acknowledges that respondentâ€™s intentions were good and had a rational basis.Â  However, respondent now acknowledges that, absent legal proceedings and appropriate authorization, he lacked authority to release the prisoners notwithstanding the countyâ€™s problems in holding them while the detention center was being renovated.Â  
Matter X
While bond hearings are scheduled two (2) times per day in the Newberry County Central Court in accordance with the direction of the Chief Justice dated November 28, 2000, it is the practice of respondent and other magistrates in Newberry County to hold special, unscheduled bond hearings in the interval between the scheduled bond hearings, making the scheduled bond hearings often unnecessary.Â  Respondent represents that, when the special bond hearings are held, they are held for the entire detention center population in need of a bond hearing and not to benefit any special defendants.Â  
Respondent now recognizes this practice may not fully conform to the directives of the Chief Justice concerning the conduct of bond hearings.Â  In the future, respondent will promptly familiarize himself with the Chief Justiceâ€™s directive and, thereafter, follow it to the letter or seek permission for a variance in procedures from the Chief Justice.Â  
Matter XI
Matthew Boland (Matthew) was charged by a South Carolina Highway Patrol trooper with driving 85 mph in a 55 mph speed zone.Â  When the case was called for trial before respondent, Matthew was not present; no bond had been posted on his behalf.Â  The trooper was present.Â  Respondent proceeded to find Matthew guilty in his absence, made the notations â€œ$425â€ (indicative of the amount of the fine imposed) and â€œNRVC,â€ and had the ticket sent to the DMV.Â  Because of the NRVC notation and $425 fine, the DMV wrote Matthew advising him that his driverâ€™s license had been suspended due to his failure to appear at trial or to post bond.
Unknown to respondent, Matthew was under the impression he did not need to appear at trial and that the ticket would be marked â€œnot guiltyâ€ in his absence.Â  Respondent reports that Magistrate Beckham later learned Matthew had been found guilty in his absence and sent word to respondent that the â€œGeneral Attorneyâ€ had wanted the ticket marked â€œnot guilty.â€ Â Respondent represents the remark remains clear in his mind because of the reference to â€œGeneral Attorneyâ€ rather than the proper reference to â€œAttorney General.â€Â  
ODC asserts, and respondent does not dispute, that, prior to the date of trial, Matthewâ€™s father (Mr. Boland) called attorney William Franklin â€œTroupâ€ Partridge, III (Troup) about the ticket. Troup referred the matter to his father, William Franklin Partridge, Jr., (Frank), an attorney practicing in Newberry County.Â  At a regularly scheduled lunch meeting, Frank told Magistrate Beckham (his son-in-law) that Frank needed to talk with the trooper about Matthewâ€™s ticket.Â  Magistrate Beckham conveyed the message to the trooper who, according to Magistrate Beckham, responded â€œtell Frank not to worry about that ticketâ€ or words to that effect.Â  Somehow Matthew came to believe he did not need to appear or post bond in connection with the ticket.Â  For purposes of this agreement, respondent does not contest these findings.Â  Â 
Respondent advises it was common practice in the Newberry County Central Court for the charging officer to fill in the information on tickets after magistrateâ€™s court was concluded based on the rulings of the hearing magistrate.Â  To respondentâ€™s best knowledge, the trooper incorrectly filled out the information on Matthewâ€™s ticket after trial by checking the â€œappearedâ€ block (when Matthew did not appear) and â€œnot guiltyâ€ (when respondent had, in open court, found Matthew guilty as charged).Â Â Â  
ODC has further determined:Â  

  
    
      
        -
         Mr. Boland called Troup after receiving notice of Matthewâ€™s license suspension from the DMV;
      
      
        -
         Troup called Magistrate Beckham (his brother-in-law) and obtained information from the records of the central magistrateâ€™s court indicating respondent had found Matthew â€œguiltyâ€ and obtained copies of the Courtâ€™s records (which indicates some confusion on the disposition of the ticket);
      
      
        -
         Troup then telephoned respondent, purportedly to inquire as to the status of the ticket based on the records of the Newberry County Central Court;[8]
      
      
        -
         respondent checked the records and advised Troup that the records indicated Matthew had been found â€œguiltyâ€ in his absence;Â Â 
      
      
        -
         Troup then told respondent that the ticket was supposed to have been marked â€œnot guiltyâ€ and had been sent to the DMV in error;
      
      
        -
         respondent told Troup that, in his judgment, there was no error, that Matthew had not appeared or posted bond, and that he was not going to change his ruling; and
      
      
        -
         respondent reports that, in the telephone conversation, Troup told him something to the effect that â€œwe will just have to file a Writ of Mandamusâ€ (emphasis in original).
      
    
  

ODC has further determined: 

  
  
    
      -
       Frank prepared legal pleadings, including an order for a Rule to Show Cause requiring respondent to appear at a hearing before Circuit Court Judge Wyatt Saunders the next business day;
    
    
      -
       Judge Saunders reports he has been unable to determine how those pleadings came to be in his office and were left on his desk by an unknown person;
    
    
      -
       Troup is Judge Saundersâ€™ former law clerk and, coincidentally (according to both Troup and Judge Saunders), dropped by Judge Saundersâ€™ chambers prior to the closing of the courthouse just to â€œsay helloâ€ to Judge Saunders the same day Judge Saunders signed the Rule to Show Cause order;
    
    
      -
       Judge Saunders asked Troup to have the pleadings served on respondent;
    
    
      -
       Sheriff Lee Foster reported he received a telephone call from Troup (whom Sheriff Foster knew personally and was aware of his employment by the State of South Carolina) who stated the Attorney General wanted the pleadings served on respondent that evening;
    
    
      -
       Sheriff Foster dispatched a deputy sheriff to Frankâ€™s house, picked up the pleadings there from Troup, and had a deputy sheriff serve them on respondent; and
    
    
      -
       the pleadings required respondent to appear before Judge Saunders the next business day to show cause why Matthewâ€™s tickets should not be changed to â€œnot guilty.â€ [9] 
    
  
  

Although he prepared the pleadings, Frank did not appear at the hearing before Judge Saunders.Â  Matthew appeared pro se, along with his father.Â  Respondent also appeared pro se.Â  Judge Saunders did not ask Matthew if he appeared for trial or why he believed he would be found â€œnot guilty.â€Â  The transcript from the proceeding indicates Matthew â€œcould not rememberâ€ who had given him copies of the materials presented to the circuit court.Â  Judge Saunders asked respondent if it would be proper to â€œoffer this citizen a trial.â€Â  In response, respondent stated he was willing to â€œhelpâ€ Matthew.Â  Judge Saunders noted that pleadings did not bear any docket number and stated on the record that respondent â€œis willing to assist youâ€ and volunteered that the circuit court was acting â€œno different in this than it would in other similar matters.â€Â  
After the case was recessed, respondent, Matthew, and Mr. Boland went into the hallway to discuss the matter.Â  Judge Saunders asked the trooperâ€™s supervisor who was also present in the courthouse for other purposes to participate in the discussion between respondent, Matthew, and Mr. Boland.Â  The supervisor agreed that the 85/55 mph ticket (a six point ticket) against Matthew would be reduced to a two point violation (speeding under 10 miles over the posted limit) and the fine would be reduced in accordance with the reduced charges.Â  Judge Saunders was advised the matter had been resolved and, thereafter, caused the records to reflect that Matthew had been convicted, pled guilty, or forfeited bond to a charge of speeding under 10 miles over the posted limit. 
The very next day, Matthew appeared before respondent, accompanied by Frank, on two additional traffic charges.Â  Respondent reduced these charges to â€œhelpâ€ Matthew because of Matthewâ€™s increasingly poor driving record.Â  
Respondent now recognizes it was judicial misconduct to negotiate a settlement with a defendant and his father even if encouraged to do so by the circuit court judge and even in the presence of and with the consent of the trooperâ€™s supervisor.Â  Respondent has represented to ODC under oath that he did not feel any pressure by the circuit court judge but, instead, just wanted to â€œhelpâ€ Matthew because of the obvious difficulties he would face due to the traffic tickets. 
Respondent has been fully cooperative with ODCâ€™s inquiries in this and all other matters addressed herein and has amended his procedures to conform with applicable guidelines as he now understands them to be.Â  
LAW
By his misconduct, respondent has violated the following Canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR:Â  Canon 1 (judge shall uphold integrity of the judiciary); Canon 1A (judge should participate in establishing, maintaining and enforcing high standards of conduct, and shall personally observe those standards so that the integrity and independence of the judiciary will be preserved); Canon 2 (judge shall avoid impropriety and the appearance of impropriety in all activities); Canon 2A (judge shall respect and comply with the law and shall act at all times in a manner that promotes public confidence in the integrity and impartiality of the judiciary); Canon 2B (judge shall not allow family, social, political or other relationships to influence the judge's judicial conduct or judgment); Canon 3 (judge shall perform the duties of judicial office impartially and diligently); Canon 3(B)(2)Â  (judge shall be faithful to the law and maintain professional competence in it; judge shall not be swayed by public clamor or fear of criticism); Canon 3B(7) (judge shall not initiate, permit, or consider
ex  parte  communications, or consider other communications made to the judge outside the presence of the parties concerning a pending proceeding); and Canon 3B(8) (judge shall dispose of all judicial matters promptly, efficiently, and fairly).Â  Respondent admits that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline pursuant to Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate the Code of Judicial Conduct) and Rule 7(a)(7) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to willfully violate a valid court order issued by a court of this State) of the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502,
SCACR.  Â Â 
CONCLUSION 
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and issue a public reprimand.Â  Because respondent no longer holds his magisterial position, a public reprimand is the most severe sanction the Court can impose for the misconduct addressed in this opinion.Â  See In re Oâ€™Kelley, 361 S.C. 30, 603 S.E.2d 410 (2004); In re Gravely, 321 S.C. 235, 467 S.E.2d 924 (1996).Â  Due to the gravity of respondentâ€™s misconduct, he shall no longer serve in any judicial capacity in this state without the Courtâ€™s permission.Â  Respondent is hereby reprimanded for his misconduct.Â  
 PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â  WALLER, J., not participating.

[1]The Newberry County Magistrateâ€™s Court recognized that, if the defendant was represented by counsel, counsel would likely offer a hearsay objection to the admission of information in the incident report (unless the report was introduced by the officer who prepared the report) and the objection would have to be sustained.Â  
[2] Respondent represents he had permission to sign the employeeâ€™s name to the time sheet and that his actions were taken with the acquiescence of and/or instructions from county administrative personnel.
[3] Respondent is romantically involved with the employee. Respondent and the employee have testified under oath that their romantic involvement did not take place until after the employee ceased to be an employee of the Newberry County Central Court System.Â Â Â Â  
[4] Respondent represents the employee was making payments on the vehicle in return for its use.Â  Â Â 
[5] See Footnote 3.
[6] Respondent represents he would not have normally discussed the matter with the trooper, but the trooperâ€™s supervisor advised respondent that he felt the ticket should be dismissed and was going to direct the trooper to do so.Â  
[7] â€œNRVCâ€ is the standard notation to indicate the defendant failed to appear or post bond and the administrative process should suspend the defendantâ€™s driverâ€™s license in accordance with applicable law.Â  
[8] ODC does not contend that respondentâ€™s conversation with Troup was an improper ex parte conversation inasmuch as respondent entered into the conversation with Troup only to discuss the status of the ticket, an administrative matter.Â Â  
[9] Respondent has no direct knowledge of many of the conclusions in this list but, for purposes of this agreement, does not dispute them.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

title: Nance v. Ozmint
description: After reviewing this case in light of Florida v. Nixon, the Court reversed the decision of the PCR court to deny relief.
text:
Robert Lee Nance (Petitioner), sentenced to death for murder, appealed from the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s denial of his application for relief


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Robert Lee Nance, Petitioner,
v.
Jon E. Ozmint, Director, South Carolina Department of
Corrections, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON REMAND FROM THE
UNITED STATES SUPREME COURT

Appeal from Florence County
John Henry Waller, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Thomas Ervin, Post Conviction Relief Judge

Opinion No.Â Â  26101
Heard November 15, 2005 - Filed January 30, 2006

Reversed


  
    
      
Teresa L. Norris, of Center for Capital Litigation, and William Norman Nettles, both of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney
General Donald J. Zelenka, and Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, of Columbia, for Respondent. 
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Robert Lee Nance (Petitioner), sentenced to death for murder, appealed from the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s denial of his application for relief.Â  This Court held that the manner in which Petitionerâ€™s trial counsel investigated, planned, and conducted his defense constituted a classic example of a complete breakdown in the adversarial process.Â  As a result, this Court granted Petitioner a new trial.Â  However, the United States Supreme Court vacated this Courtâ€™s judgment and remanded this case for consideration in light of Florida v. Nixon.[1]
Factual / Procedural Background
The facts surrounding the incident are not in dispute and are outlined in this Courtâ€™s previous opinion:

The victims, Robert and Violet Fraley, were attacked at home where they lived alone.[2]Â  On the night of the intrusion, Mr. Fraley testified that he and his wife went to bed around 9:30 or 10:00 p.m.Â  Mr. Fraley awoke to the sound of someone knocking on the front door of the house.Â  Mr. Fraley testified that he saw a man standing on the porch, and that the man asked him if he could come in to use the phone because his truck had broken down.Â  Mr. Fraley told him he could use the phone outside in his shop.Â  When the man said he did not have a light to see his way to the shed, Mr. Fraley left the door to get him a flashlight.Â  Mr. Fraley testified that when he unlatched the door to hand over the light, the man forced the door open and immediately began stabbing him with a screwdriver.
At some point, Mrs. Fraley entered the room and tried to help Mr. Fraley as he tried unsuccessfully to get away from the intruder.Â  Mr. Fraley was bleeding profusely and his wife was trying to wipe up blood while the intruder was demanding money and the keys to their car.Â  Mrs. Fraley retrieved both of their wallets and their keys and gave approximately $194 in cash and the keys to the intruder.Â  Mr. Fraley testified that he pleaded with the intruder not to kill him and his wife, but that the intruder replied that he was going to kill both of them.Â  The intruder then raped and killed Mrs. Fraley.Â  Miraculously, Mr. Fraley survived the attack but was hospitalized for thirteen days.Â  
Petitioner was arrested in the early morning hours following the attack after he was pulled over driving the Fraleysâ€™ Cadillac.Â  There was blood on his clothes that was later determined to be Mrs. Fraleyâ€™s.Â  The car also contained a bank envelope that was taken from the Fraleysâ€™ home during the attack.Â  Two people were in the car with Petitioner when he was stopped.Â  One person fled the scene and was never apprehended.Â  The other person, Erskine Green, testified at Petitionerâ€™s trial that he did not know Petitioner and that Petitioner had picked him and the other man up on the side of the road.Â  

Petitioner was convicted of murder, criminal sexual conduct (CSC) in the first degree, first-degree burglary, assault and battery with intent to kill (ABIK), and armed robbery.Â  He was sentenced to death on the murder charge.Â  He was also sentenced to life for burglary, thirty years for CSC, twenty years for ABIK, and twenty-five years for armed robbery.Â  His convictions and sentences were affirmed on direct appeal.Â  State v. Nance, 320 S.C. 501, 466 S.E.2d 349 (1996).Â  Subsequently, Petitioner filed a PCR application.Â  The PCR court denied relief and Petitioner appealed. 
This Court granted relief relying on United States v. Cronic[3] because Petitioner did not receive effective assistance of counsel due to the failure of counsel to challenge the prosecutionâ€™s case against Petitioner.Â  Nance v. Frederick, 358 S.C. 480, 596 S.E.2d 62 (2004).Â  The Court held that the case represented â€œa classic Cronic ineffectiveness case, falling under the second Cronic scenario because there was a total breakdown in the adversarial process during both the guilt phase and penalty phase of Petitionerâ€™s trial.â€Â  Id. at 488, 596 S.E.2d at 66.
The United States Supreme Court vacated this Courtâ€™s judgment and remanded the case in light of Florida v. Nixon.Â  In Nixon, the Court held that presumed prejudice as outlined by Cronic is reserved for cases in which counsel fails to meaningfully oppose the prosecutionâ€™s case.Â  Nixon, 543 U.S. at ___.Â  Accordingly, the following issue is presented to this Court for review:
What is the impact of Florida v. Nixon on this case?
Law/Analysis
Cronic and Strickland
Petitioner argues that this Court should hold that counsel was ineffective and grant relief.Â  We agree. 
Â â€œThe very premise of our adversary system of criminal justice is that partisan advocacy on both sides of a case will best promote the ultimate objective that the guilty be convicted and the innocent go free.â€Â  Herring v. New York, 422 U.S. 853, 862 (1975).Â  
The Sixth Amendment guarantees that every criminal defendant shall receive â€œAssistance of Counselâ€ in establishing his defense.Â  U.S. Const. amend. VI.Â  On May 14, 1984, the United States Supreme Court handed down two opinions holding that the Sixth Amendment requires that a criminal defendant receive effective assistance of counsel.Â  United States v. Cronic, 466 U.S. 648 (1984); Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).
Â  Strickland and Cronic are companion cases applying the same analysis, but with a different emphasis.Â  Both Strickland and Cronic direct that a defendant must ordinarily make two showings in order to prevail on an ineffective assistance claim.Â  â€œFirst, the defendant must show that counselâ€™s performance was deficient.â€Â  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 687; Cronic, 466 U.S. at 666 (explaining that absent specific â€œcircumstances mak[ing] it unlikely that the defendant could have received the effective assistance,â€ he can make out an ineffective assistance claim â€œonly by pointing to specific errors made by trial counselâ€).Â  This requires the defendant to demonstrate that â€œcounsel's representation fell below an objective standard of reasonableness.â€Â  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 687-88; Cronic, 466 U.S. at 666 n. 41 (noting that â€œclaims based on specified errors ... should be evaluated under the standards enunciated in Stricklandâ€).Â  â€œSecond the defendant must show that the deficient performance prejudiced the defense.Â  This requires showing that counselâ€™s errors were so serious as to deprive the
defendant of a fair trial, a trial whose result is reliable.â€Â  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 687.
The Supreme Court also recognized in both Strickland and Cronic that in certain circumstances â€œprejudice is presumedâ€ because prejudice â€œis so likely that case-by-case inquiry ... is not worth the cost.â€Â  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 692 (citing Cronic, 466 U.S. at 658).Â  In Cronic, the Court identified three distinct situations in which a presumption of prejudice is appropriate.Â  First, prejudice is presumed when the defendant is completely denied counsel â€œat a critical stage of his trial.â€Â  Cronic, 466 U.S. at 659.Â  Second, per-se prejudice occurs if there has been a constructive denial of counsel.Â  This happens when a lawyer â€œentirely fails to subject the prosecution's case to meaningful adversarial testing,â€ thus making â€œthe adversary process itself presumptively unreliable.â€ Id.Â  Third, the Court identified certain instances â€œwhen although counsel is available to assist the accused during trial, the likelihood that any lawyer, even a fully competent one, could provide effective assistance is so small that a presumption of prejudice is appropriate without inquiry into the actual conduct of the trial.â€Â  Id.Â  (citing Powell v. Alabama, 287 U.S. 45 (1932)).Â  A finding of per-se prejudice under any of these three prongs is â€œan extremely high showing for a criminal defendant to make.â€Â  Brown v. French, 147 F.3d 307, 313 (4th Cir. 1998).
Absent these narrow circumstances of presumed prejudice under
Cronic, defendants must show actual prejudice under Strickland. See Strickland, 466 U.S. at 692; Cronic, 466 U.S. at 666 and n. 41.Â  Actual prejudice requires the defendant to â€œshow that there is a reasonable probability that, but for counsel's unprofessional errors, the result of the proceeding would have been different.Â  A reasonable probability is a probability sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcome.â€Â  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 694.
Florida v. Nixon reaffirmed the notion that per-se prejudice occurs infrequently.Â  In Nixon, the United States Supreme Court held that entering a guilty plea on behalf of a defendant without his express consent did not constitute ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  Nixon, 543 U.S. at ___.Â  The Court opined that the decision to plead guilty was a strategy employed by trial counsel in an effort to present mitigating evidence at sentencing in an attempt to save the defendantâ€™s life.Â  Id. atÂ  ___.Â  Further, the Court held that Cronicâ€™s presumed prejudice standard was only used for those cases where counsel fails to â€œfunction in any meaningful sense as the Governmentâ€™s adversary.â€Â  Id. at ___. 
In light of the recent holding in Nixon, we believe the present case represents one of the rare cases where counsel â€œentirely fails to subject the prosecution's case to meaningful adversarial testing.â€Â  Moreover, counsel did not act as an adversary to the prosecutionâ€™s case, but instead helped to bolster the case against his client.
This Courtâ€™s previous opinion set forth the following in an effort to detail the deficiencies in counselâ€™s representation:Â  
Trial Presentation

Following Petitionerâ€™s arrest, defense counsel was appointed as Petitionerâ€™s lead counsel.Â  At the time he was appointed, defense counsel had either recently suffered from or was then suffering from pneumonia, gout, ulcers, diabetes, alcoholism, and congestive heart failure.Â  During the trial he was taking various prescription medications, including Valium, Lopressor, Isocet, and Tenormin.Â  At the PCR hearing, Petitionerâ€™s experts testified that the side effects of those medications included impaired memory, lack of sleep, and sedation.Â  Defense counselâ€™s testimony at the PCR hearing indicated that he remembered very little from the trial that took place 5 years before the PCR hearing.Â  
An attorney, who had only been practicing law for eighteen months, was appointed as co-counsel.Â  Co-counsel testified at the PCR hearing that Petitionerâ€™s mother was the only family member who was interviewed prior to trial; that he did not recall that anyone investigated Petitionerâ€™s background; and that no one had requested Petitionerâ€™s records from the Department of Corrections. 
The psychologist who planned to offer expert testimony concerning Petitionerâ€™s mental health, Dr. Dewitt (Dewitt), asked defense counsel for Petitionerâ€™s medical records, social history, statements from family members, and statements from the Department of Corrections staff but never received them.Â  He received Petitionerâ€™s hospital records a few hours before trial.


Guilt Phase

When introducing himself in his opening statement to the jury, co-counsel said, â€œI did not ask [to represent the Petitioner], I was simply appointed.Â  [defense counsel], as the public defender, did not ask for this case either.Â  He was just appointed to represent Mr. Nance.â€Â  In addition, defense counsel presented only three witnesses to testify on behalf of Petitionerâ€™s defense: a corrections officer, an unqualified expert, and Petitionerâ€™s sister.
Defense counselâ€™s first witness, a Florence County detention center officer, testified that while in prison, Petitioner threw urine at a female corrections officer.[4]Â Â  On cross-examination, the officer testified that this episode was Petitionerâ€™s only incident of misbehavior during the seven-month period that Petitioner was under his watch.
The defenseâ€™s second witness, Dewitt, testified about Petitionerâ€™s mental health. Based on only two meetings with the Petitioner, Dewitt opined that Petitioner more closely resembled a criminal who was guilty but mentally ill.Â  Defense counsel was not successful in qualifying Dewitt as an expert.
The defense rested after Dewittâ€™s testimony.Â  The trial judge then granted defense counselâ€™s request to reopen his presentation so that Petitionerâ€™s sister could testify.Â  Defense counsel failed to prepare the sisterâ€™s testimony but asked that she testify about Petitionerâ€™s childhood.Â  The sister testified that Petitioner was an abnormal child: pretending to be an undertaker, he buried one of his brothers; pulled a gun on their father; stabbed himself with a broken bottle; and killed their pets. 
In sum, the testimony that defense counsel presented in Petitionerâ€™s guilt phase defense consisted of testimony of a corrections officer concerning the only incident of misconduct that Petitioner committed while incarcerated; an opinion by an uninformed psychiatrist who was not qualified as an expert; and unprepared testimony of Petitionerâ€™s sister about Petitionerâ€™s oddities as a child.

Sentencing Phase

Defense counselâ€™s mitigation presentation during the sentencing phase of the trial lasted seven minutes.Â  Counsel began by waiving the opening statement and then incorporated the meager amount of defense testimony elicited during the guilt phase. Â 
Defense counsel then presented the testimony of a corrections officer of the Florence Detention Center, who testified that Petitioner was taking two prescription medications, Cogentin and Haldol, and that Petitioner had taken Haldol that morning.[5]Â  Counsel presented no further testimony, to which the trial judge responded by asking, â€œAre you ready to go to the jury?â€Â  Counsel responded, â€œWe incorporate what we feel, Your Honor -- the doctor and the other testimony by the sister would be repetitious.â€Â  The judge then replied, â€œDo you need any time to collect your thoughts?Â  This is rather quick.â€[6]Â  Co-counsel gave the closing argument, refusing to plead for Petitionerâ€™s life and referring to Petitioner as a â€œsickâ€ man who did â€œsick things.â€
We find that this trial presentation, in its entirety, represents a classic Cronic ineffectiveness case, falling under the second Cronic scenario because there was a total breakdown in the adversarial process during both the guilt phase and penalty phase of Petitionerâ€™s trial.Â  For the reasons set forth below, we presume Petitioner was prejudiced, and accordingly, grant him a new trial.
First, Petitioner was disadvantaged from the outset because lead defense counsel was in ill health and on heavy medication, and co-counsel had only practiced law for eighteen months.Â Â  
Second, in aid of its claim that Petitioner was mentally ill, the defense had wanted Petitioner to appear in the courtroom in his natural demeanor, unaffected by the administration of psychotropic drugs.Â  The defense was successful in getting the trial judge to order such.Â  Nevertheless, defense counsel failed to inform the jail personnel of the trial judgeâ€™s order that Petitioner be taken off the anti-psychotic drug, Haldol. Consequently, Petitioner remained in a drug-influenced demeanor during the entire trial, and the jury never observed his natural demeanor.Â  
Third, the trial had just begun when co-counsel communicated to the jury that neither he nor defense counsel wanted to be there.
Fourth, while defense counsel may have been pursuing a defense of guilty but mentally ill (GBMI),[7] he failed to qualify his own expert.Â  Further, by eliciting the unprepared testimony of Petitionerâ€™s sister only after defense psychologist Dewitt testified, defense counsel failed to give his unqualified expert, at minimum, the opportunity to inform the jury of how the sisterâ€™s testimony of Petitionerâ€™s mental irregularities as a child could lead to a conclusion that Petitioner was mentally ill at the time of the murder. 
Fifth, defense counsel presented no adaptability evidence at the sentencing hearing.Â  In fact, by merely incorporating the testimony elicited from the guilt phase, defense counsel gave the impression that Petitioner had not adapted to confinement, because the only evidence that had been presented concerning his confinement was the urine-throwing incident.
During the PCR hearing, Petitioner presented testimony to show that the urine-throwing incident was the only instance of bad behavior during confinement.Â  In fact, Petitioner was selected as the Manning Correctional Institutionâ€™s inmate of the year and was nominated for the Department of Correctionsâ€™ inmate of the year.Â  He also sang in the prison choir and participated in other Christian activities.Â  A jail administrator and prison minister testified that Petitioner was a model inmate.Â  Defense counsel could have easily discovered this adaptability evidence prior to trial but failed to do so.[8]
Sixth, defense counsel presented no mitigating social history evidence to explain the Petitionerâ€™s odd childhood behavior to which his sister referred to during the guilt phase.Â  Defense counsel failed to reveal that Petitioner was beaten throughout his childhood; his father was an alcoholic who fought with many family members; he was treated with alcohol as a child in lieu of over-the-counter medication; and he grew up in a family of extreme poverty and physical deprivation.Â  
Seventh, defense counselâ€™s seven-minute mitigation presentation failed to provide the jury with any insight concerning Petitionerâ€™s mental illness.Â  At the PCR hearing, Petitioner introduced evidence that he has a family history of schizophrenia, he has a history of hearing voices in his head, and he has suffered neurological damage.Â  
Finally, during the closing argument, co-counsel failed to plead for Petitionerâ€™s life and referred to him as a â€œsickâ€ man.

Nance, 358 S.C. at 485-88, 596 S.E.2d at 65-66.
The above outlined trial presentation details the complete failure to conduct a defense by trial counsel.Â  We hold that this case represents a very rare situation where counsel failed to provide an adversarial challenge to the prosecution.Â  We find it most compelling that in the present case counsel abandoned his role as defense counsel and in fact helped to bolster the case against his client.Â  In particular, counselâ€™s statement that his client was â€œa sick manâ€ who has done â€œsick thingsâ€ points to the fact that he was not acting as defense counsel and failed â€œto functionâ€¦ as the Governmentâ€™s adversary.â€Â  Â See Jones v. Barnes, 463 U.S. 745, 758 (1983) (stating that in order to satisfy the Constitution, counsel must function as an advocate for the defendant, as opposed to a friend of the court); Ferri v. Ackerman, 444 U.S. 193, 204 (1979) (stating that an indispensable element of the effective performance of [defense counsel's] responsibilities is the ability to act independently of the Government and to oppose it in adversary litigation).Â  In addition, counsel called a defense witness who testified about Petitionerâ€™s one incident of misbehavior in jail.Â  Finally, Petitionerâ€™s sister testified as to his propensity for killing animals as a child.Â  These witnesses, in addition to counselâ€™s opening and closing statements, helped to further bolster the prosecutionâ€™s case against Petitioner rather than providing him with a defense.
We again recognize that this type of â€œconsistently inept form of lawyer conduct [is not] acceptable in this state, nor will we employ a prejudice analysis, for â€˜[defense] counselâ€™s ineffectiveness [is] so pervasive as to render a particularized prejudice inquiry unnecessary.â€™â€Â  Nance, 358 S.C. at 490, 596 S.E.2d at 67. (citing Frett v. State, 298 S.C. 54, 56, 378 S.E.2d 249, 251 (1988)).Â  As a result, we hold that counsel was ineffective under Cronic and failed to act as an adversary to the prosecution, but instead helped to reinforce the case against his client.
Conclusion
Based on the above reasoning, we again reverse the PCRâ€™s decision to deny relief after reconsideration of the issue in light of Florida v. Nixon. 
 MOORE, BURNETT, PLEICONES, J.J., and Acting Justice James C. Williams
concur.

[1] Florida v. Nixon, 543 U.S. 175 (2004).
[2] Mr. and Mrs. Fraley were 78 and 73 years old respectively at the time of the attack.
[3] United States v. Cronic, 466 U.S. 648 (1984).
[4] At the PCR hearing, Petitionerâ€™s PCR counsel presented testimony that the reason why Petitioner threw urine at the female office was because she reminded him of his aunt.Â  
[5] The trial judge forbade Petitioner from taking any antipsychotic drugs during trial.Â  Haldol is a very strong antipsychotic drug used in the treatment of acute schizophrenia and acute psychosis, controlling a patientâ€™s tendency towards aggression and agitation.Â  
http://www.psyweb.com/Drughtm/halope.html 
[6] This is an example of the trial judgeâ€™s commendable attempt to insure that defense counsel was effectively representing his client.Â  Unfortunately, the trial judgeâ€™s ability to hold defense counsel to his constitutional obligation to effectively represent his client was greatly limited by (1) the desultory manner in which defense counsel tried this case and (2) the fact that at the time this case was tried, South Carolina common law provided little guidance as to what constituted an attorneyâ€™s complete failure to provide effective representation.Â  We hope that this opinion provides some clarity as to what does not constitute effective representation.Â  
[7] Dewitt testified that Petitionerâ€™s mental incapacity did not rise to the level of the Mâ€™Naughten standard for insanity but did opine that he met the standard for GBMI.Â  Despite evidence of Petitionerâ€™s mental incapacity, defense counsel failed to raise the issue of whether Petitioner was competent to stand trial.Â  
[8] The United States Supreme Court has recently recognized that defense counsel must conduct a reasonable investigation â€œto discover all reasonably available mitigation evidence and evidence to rebut any aggravating evidence that may be introduced by the prosecutor.â€Â  Wiggins v. Smith, 539 U.S. 510, 524-25 (2003) (citation omitted).
