title: Avant v. Willowglen Academy
description: This is a workers' compensation case.  The Court granted a writ of certiorari to review Avant v. Willowglen Academy, 356 S.C. 181, 588 S.E.2d 125 (Ct. App. 2003).  The Court affirmed the Court of Appeals' decision that the assigned-risk insurance carrier was not responsible for the workers' compensation claim.  Rather, the voluntary insurance carrier was responsible, because it was the only carrier with an effective policy on the date of the incident that led to the claim.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Marty K. Avant, Employee, Claimant,
v.
Willowglen Academy, Employer, and United Heartland and Travelers Property Casualty Co., Carriers, of which United Heartland is
Petitioner,
and Travelers Property Casualty Co. is Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Williamsburg County
Â L. Henry McKellar, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26102
Heard October 18, 2005 - Filed January 30, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Roy A. Howell, III and Kirsten L. Barr, both of Trask & Howell, LLC, of Mount Pleasant, for Petitioner.
Johnnie W. Baxley, III, of Wilson, Jones, Carter & Baxley, LLC, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE PLEICONES: This is a workersâ€™ compensation case.Â  Respondent Travelers Property Casualty Co. (Travelers) moved the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission to identify Petitioner United Heartland (United) as the insurer responsible for the claim of Willowglen Academy (Willowglen).Â  The single commissioner held United responsible.Â  The appellate panel of the commission affirmed in part and reversed in part, holding Travelers and United equally responsible.Â  The circuit court affirmed in part and reversed in part, holding Travelers solely responsible.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed, holding United solely responsible.Â  Avant v. Willowglen Academy, 356 S.C. 181, 588 S.E.2d 125 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion and now affirm.
FACTS
Travelers insured Marty Avantâ€™s employer, Willowglen Academy, through an assigned-risk workersâ€™ compensation policy administered by the National Council on Compensation Insurance (NCCI).Â  The policy was effective from August 24, 1996 through August 24, 1997.Â  
Although covered by the assigned-risk policy with Travelers, Willowglen procured voluntary insurance from United, effective July 1, 1997.Â  An employer able to procure voluntary insurance is ineligible for assigned-risk insurance,[1] but Willowglen neither notified Travelers or the NCCI of the voluntary coverage nor attempted to cancel the assigned-risk policy.Â  More important, Willowglen actually renewed the assigned-risk policy with Travelers for the period August 24, 1997 through August 24, 1998 (the renewal policy).
On September 6, 1997, a date within both Travelersâ€™ and Unitedâ€™s respective stated coverage periods, Marty Avant was injured.Â  Willowglen submitted the claim to Travelers, which remained unaware of the voluntary policy with United.Â  Travelers accepted the claim and began providing benefits.Â  
Travelers eventually became aware of the voluntary policy, in January 1998.Â  Travelers issued a notice of cancelation retroactive to July 1, 1997, the date on which Willowglen acquired voluntary insurance from United.[2]Â  Travelers refunded all premiums paid by Willowglen for assigned-risk coverage after that date.
Subsequently, Travelers filed a motion with the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission to identify United as the sole responsible carrier.Â  The single commissioner relied on the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Assigned Risk Plan (the Assigned Risk Plan or the Plan), which was filed with the Department of Insurance by the NCCI and approved by the Director of the Department of Insurance.Â  The commissioner then held that under the Assigned Risk Plan, Travelersâ€™ assigned-risk coverage terminated as a matter of law on July 1, 1997, the date on which United began providing voluntary coverage.Â  The commissioner therefore ruled that United was solely responsible for Willowglenâ€™s claim.
On appeal, the commissionâ€™s appellate panel affirmed in part and reversed in part.Â  Preliminarily, the panel held that the Assigned Risk Plan does not â€œsupersedeâ€ the workersâ€™ compensation regulations.Â  The panel then found that both Travelers and United â€œintended to have coverage on September 6, 1997â€ and that â€œ[e]quity, in the light of the circumstances of this case, require[d]â€ that United and Travelers equally share responsibility.
On further appeal, the circuit court affirmed in part and reversed in part.Â  The court found the Plan inapplicable and held Travelers alone responsible under the workersâ€™ compensation regulations.Â  According to the court, Travelersâ€™ attempt to retroactively cancel its coverage was ineffective because the regulations do not permit retroactive cancelation.Â  Also under the regulations, Travelers was presumed responsible because the effective date of its renewal policy (August 24, 1997) was later than that of Unitedâ€™s voluntary policy (July 1, 1997).Â  See 25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-409(A) (1990) (addressing dual coverage); infra, note 5.
On further review, the Court of Appeals reversed.Â  The court held that the Assigned Risk Plan has the force of law and determined that the Plan â€œshould be read in conjunction with the Act and its regulations and be accorded effect under the facts of this case given [the Plan] addresses matters where the Act is silent.â€Â  Avant, 356 S.C. at 187-89, 588 S.E.2d at 128-29.Â  The Court of Appeals then held that Travelersâ€™ coverage terminated as a matter of law as soon as United issued its voluntary policy.Â  Id.Â  Consequently, the court ruled that United was solely responsible.Â  
ISSUES

I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Whether the Assigned Risk Plan has the force of law.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Whether Travelers or United is the responsible carrier.

ANALYSIS
We adhere to our holding in Rodriguez v. Romero 363 S.C. 80, 88, 610 S.E.2d 488, 92 (2005), that the Plan has the force of law.Â  In addition, we hold that United is responsible for Willowglenâ€™s claim.Â  We therefore affirm.
I.Â  Force of Law
Under the Administrative Procedures Act, â€œâ€˜[p]olicy or guidance issued by an agency other than in a regulation does not have the force of law.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-10(4) (Supp. 2002).Â  None of the provisions of the Assigned Risk Plan has been promulgated as a regulation.Â  United argues that the lack of promulgation requires a finding that the Plan lacks the force of law, meaning only the workersâ€™ compensation regulations are controlling.Â  See also Rodriguez, 363 S.C. at 88-89, 610 S.E.2d at 492-93 (Toal, C.J., dissenting); Avant, 356 S.C. at 193-97, 588 S.E.2d at 131-33 (Anderson, J., dissenting).Â  We disagree.
The General Assembly has delegated certain authority over assigned-risk insurance to the Director of the Department of Insurance.[3]Â  South Carolina Code section 38-73-540(A)(1)[4] states that â€œany mechanism designed to implementâ€ the assigned-risk agreement executed by the stateâ€™s insurers â€œmust be submitted in writing to the director or his designee for approval prior to use, together with such additional information as the director or his designee may reasonably require.â€Â  The Code does not require that the implementation mechanism be promulgated as a regulation.Â  Rather, the mechanism attains the force of law when it is approved by the Director of the Department of Insurance.
Moreover, the provisions of the Plan prevail over the workersâ€™ compensation regulations.Â  Code section 38-73-540 specifically addresses assigned-risk insurance and the mechanism for implementing assigned-risk agreements, whereas the regulations address workersâ€™ compensation generally.Â  The principle that more specific rules prevail over general ones applies, and the Plan is the product of a more specific statute.Â  See Mims v. Alston, 312 S.C. 311, 313, 440 S.E.2d 357, 358-59 (1994) (applying the principle).Â  The Plan controls with respect to issues it addresses.
In comparison, the Court of Appeals held that the Plan â€œshould be read in conjunction with [the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act] and its regulations and be accorded effect under the facts of this case given [the Plan] addresses matters where the Act is silent.â€Â  Avant, 356 S.C. at 189, 588 S.E.2d at 129 (quoted with approval in Rodriguez, 363 S.C. at 88, 610 S.E.2d at 492).Â  Because this passage could be interpreted to mean that the Plan fills gaps in the workersâ€™ compensation regulations, we clarify that the regulations fill gaps in the Plan.Â  As discussed below, the Plan resolves the issues in this case, so there is no need to resort to the workersâ€™ compensation regulations.
II.Â  Responsible Carrier
As stated above, Marty Avant was injured on September 6, 1997, a date within the stated coverage periods of both Travelersâ€™ renewal policy and Unitedâ€™s voluntary policy.Â  After becoming aware of Willowglenâ€™s voluntary policy with United, Travelers canceled its assigned-risk policy retroactive to July 1, 1997, the effective date of Unitedâ€™s voluntary policy, and refunded all premiums paid by Willowglen for assigned-risk coverage after that date.
The first issue is whether Travelersâ€™ renewal policy in fact became effective on its stated effective date, August 24, 1997.Â  If it did, then there was dual coverage on September 6, 1997, and because the Plan does not address dual coverage, a workersâ€™ compensation regulation applies ... in favor of United.[5]Â  For the reasons stated below, we find that Travelersâ€™ renewal policy never became effective, so the dual-coverage issue does not arise.
In Rodriguez, we held that the assigned-risk policy at issue never became effective because the insured, like Willowglen here, procured voluntary coverage prior to the assigned-risk policyâ€™s effective date.Â  Rodriguez involved a more recent edition of the Assigned Risk Plan, however, and that edition contained language different from this edition.Â  That edition stated:

  
[A]ny insurer that wishes to insure an employer as voluntary business may do so at any time.Â  If
such insurer is not the contract carrier, the contract carrier shall cancel its policy pro rata and the coverage
shall automatically terminate as of the effective date of the voluntary insurerâ€™s policy.
  
(all but â€œpro rataâ€ quoted in Rodriguez, 363 S.C. at 85-86, 610
S.E.2d at 491 (emphasis in opinion altered)).

The edition involved in this case states:

[A]ny insurer that wishes to insure an employer as voluntary business may do so at any time.Â  If
 such insurer is not the assigned carrier, the assigned carrier shall cancel its policy pro rata and the assignment
shall automatically terminate as of the effective date of the voluntary insurerâ€™s policy.

United argues that the difference is critical.Â  United emphasizes that the assignment flows from the insurerâ€™s contractual relationship with the other insurers participating in the Assigned Risk Plan, whereas coverage flows from the insurance policy, which represents the relationship between the insurer and the insured.Â  According to United, the edition of the Plan involved here plainly addresses the automatic termination of only the assignment.Â  Based on the principle inclusio unius est exclusio alterius, United asserts that under this edition of the Plan, assigned-risk coverage does not automatically terminate upon the commencement of voluntary coverage.Â  See, e.g., German Evangelical Lutheran Church of Charleston v. City of Charleston, 352 S.C. 600, 606-07, 576 S.E.2d 150, 153 (2003) (applying the principle); Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 86-87, 533 S.E.2d 578, 582 (2000) (same).Â  Accordingly, United claims, Travelersâ€™ assigned-risk coverage with Willowglen continued to exist until Travelers affirmatively canceled the renewal policy, after September 6, 1997.[6]
At first glance, Unitedâ€™s argument is appealing.Â  This edition of the Plan does say â€œassignment,â€ not â€œcoverage.â€Â  Nevertheless, the effect of the automatic termination of the assignment is the automatic termination of coverage.Â  Without the assignment there never would have been any policy or coverage.Â  We therefore hold that Travelersâ€™ assigned-risk coverage automatically terminated when Unitedâ€™s voluntary coverage commenced.Â  Consequently, coverage under the renewal policy never became effective.Â  Cf. Rodriguez, 363 S.C. at 82-83, 88, 610 S.E.2d at 489-90, 492 (involving an insured who procured assigned-risk insurance after procuring voluntary coverage, and holding that the assigned-risk policy never became effective). Â There was no dual coverage on September 6, 1997.Â  United was the only carrier.
We see no significance in the issues raised by United related to the timing and retroactivity of Travelersâ€™ cancelation of the policy.Â  See Avant, 356 S.C. at 191, 588 S.E.2d at 130 (addressing the issues and holding that the Plan â€œallows for this retroactive cancellationâ€).Â  As we have stated, coverage under Travelersâ€™ renewal policy never went into effect.Â  United was the only carrier providing workersâ€™ compensation coverage on September 6, 1997, so United is solely responsible for the claim.Â  
CONCLUSION
United was the only carrier covering Willowglen when Marty Avant was injured.Â  United is therefore solely responsible for the claim.Â  The decision of the Court of Appeals is 
 AFFIRMED.Â Â Â  
 MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, J.J., concur.Â  TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion.
 Chief Justice Toal: I respectfully dissent.Â  In my view, the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act and the regulations promulgated pursuant to the Act are the sole authorities for determining the responsibility for providing workersâ€™ compensation coverage.Â  For this reason, I would reverse the holding of the court of appeals and affirm the circuit courtâ€™s finding that Travelers, not United, is responsible in this case.
As I stated in Rodriguez,[7] the majority misconstrues the law to the extent that it reads the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act in conjunction with the guidelines set forth by the National Council on Compensation Insurance (NCCI).Â  The NCCI is not a rulemaking body, and furthermore, the NCCI possesses no authority to promulgate regulations with any binding force in South Carolina.[8]Â  The NCCI is simply an advisory body that provides its subscribers with information and data analysis services.
Like Rodriguez, at issue in this case are NCCI provisions regarding how assigned risk insurance policies should be terminated when an insured obtains voluntary coverage at a later time.Â  In my opinion, the majority continues to misinterpret S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-73-540(A)(1) to grant the director of the Department of Insurance the discretionary authority to adopt binding regulations governing assigned risk insurance policies.Â  The statute does not grant such power to the director, but instead allows the director to approve agreements made among assigned risk insurance carriers.Â  Any approved agreement would of course bind the agreeing parties, but the question of whether these agreements bind an individual insured is an entirely different matter.Â  
Any agreement that has not undergone the process of regulatory approval called for in the Administrative Procedures Act cannot be viewed as a regulation that carries the force of law.Â  Furthermore, unless these agreements or their terms appear in the individual assigned risk insurance policies, it is clear that the terms of these agreements cannot be viewed as binding contractual provisions.Â  The assigned risk policy at issue in this case says nothing about termination of the policy upon the purchase of a voluntary policy by the insured.Â  Therefore, I would rely solely on the Workersâ€™ Compensation act and its corresponding regulations to determine coverage.
The applicable workersâ€™ compensation regulation provides that when there are two insurance policies securing the same liability, the policy with the later effective date is responsible for coverage.Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-409(A) (1976).Â  In the instant case, Travelersâ€™ policy has an effective date of August 24, 1997 and Unitedâ€™s policy has an effective date of July 1, 1997.Â  Pursuant to Regulation 64-409(A), I would hold that Travelers is the proper carrier because its policy has the later effective date.
With this decision, the majority has significantly weakened South Carolinaâ€™s Administrative Procedures Act and, in my view, improperly empowered the head of an administrative agency to promulgate rules having the force of law.Â  The legislature may not empower the head of an agency to unilaterally make declarations carrying the binding force of law; therefore, we cannot interpret Â§ 38-73-540(A)(1) in this manner.Â  I find it extremely telling that the majority would give binding force to these NCCI regulations which do not appear in the State Register, have not been debated in the Legislature, and are published in no public resource.Â  Although the majority is arguably not creating â€œsecret lawâ€ in the sense that it existed in several agencies prior to the enactment of the APA, unfortunately, it appears we now must purchase an NCCI subscription to ascertain the particulars of South Carolina workersâ€™ compensation law.Â  
Accordingly, I would reverse the court of appeals and affirm the circuit courtâ€™s finding that Travelers is the responsible carrier.

[1] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-73-540(A) (2002).
[2] Travelers initially issued a notice of cancelation effective March 19, 1998, which is not germane to the issues before us.
[3] Whether the delegation is lawful is not an issue before us.
[4] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-73-540(A)(1) (2002).
[5] Regulation 67-409(A) states: 

When duplicate or dual coverage exists by
 reason of two different insurance carriers
 issuing two policies to the same employer
 securing the same liability, the Commission
 shall presume the policy with the later
 effective date is in force and the earlier
 policy terminated on the effective date of the
 later policy. 

25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-409(A) (1990).
Because its policyâ€™s stated effective date is later than that of Unitedâ€™s policy, Travelers would be presumed responsible if Regulation 67-409(A) were controlling. 
[6] As mentioned above, in 1998 Travelers canceled its policy retroactive to July 1, 1997.Â  As discussed below, United argues that this retroactive cancelation was invalid.
[7] Rodriguez v. Romero, 363 S.C. 80, 88-89, 610 S.E.2d 488, 492-93 (2005) (Toal, C.J. dissenting).Â  
[8] Under South Carolina law, the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission is responsible for promulgating all regulations relating to the administration of the workersâ€™ compensation laws.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-3-30 (1976).

title: McMillan v. Oconee Memorial Hospital
description: The Court reversed the trial courtâ€™s decision denying Oconeeâ€™s motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict.  The Court held that a cause of action for civil conspiracy could not be maintained against a single entity.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Marion R. McMillan, M.D. and Blue Ridge Medical Specialties, P.A., Respondents/Appellants,
v.
Oconee Memorial Hospital, Inc., Appellant/Respondent,
and
Anesthesiology Consultants of the Upstate, P.A.,
Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Oconee County
Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26103
Heard May 17, 2005 - Filed January 30, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
V. Clark Price, Carroll H. Roe, Jr., and Dana M. Lahey, all of Roe, Cassidy, Coates & Price, of Greenville, for Appellant/Respondent Oconee Memorial Hospital, Inc.
D. Randle Moody, of Roe, Cassidy, Coates & Price, of Greenville, for Respondent/Appellant Anesthesiology Consultants of the Upstate, P.A.
Raymond E. Lark, Jr., of Austin, Lewis & Rogers, of Columbia, for Respondent/Appellant Marion R. McMillan, M.D. and Blue Ridge Medical Specialties, P.A.
Stuart M. Andrews, Jr. and Merritt G. Abney, both of Nelson, Mullins, Riley & Scarborough, of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae South Carolina Hospital Association. 
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This case arose out of the events surrounding Oconee Memorial Hospitalâ€™s (Oconee) decision to offer anesthesiology and internal medical services on an exclusive basis.Â  A jury returned a verdict against Oconee.Â  The trial court reduced the verdict pursuant to the charitable immunity statute.Â  This appeal followed.Â  After certifying this case for review pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, we reverse the trial courtâ€™s denial of Oconeeâ€™s motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict.Â  
Factual / Procedural Background
Oconee is a private eleemosynary (charitable) hospital.Â  Dr. McMillan has been a member of the medical staff at Oconee for almost 13 years and specializes in anesthesiology and internal medicine.Â  Additionally, Dr. McMillan is the sole shareholder of Blue Ridge Medical Specialties, P.A. (collectively referred to as McMillan). 
For several years prior to this litigation, McMillan performed anesthesiology services at Oconee alongside the doctors of Anesthesiology Consultants of the Upstate, P.A. (Upstate).Â  But after McMillan formed his own practice group, the two became competitors.Â  During this period, the anesthesiology services at the hospital operated on an open-staff basis, therefore, all physicians with the appropriate privileges were permitted to practice anesthesiology and pain management.Â  The development of two competing practice groups at Oconee, however, was problematic.Â  As a result, the board at Oconee decided to pursue exclusive contracts for its anesthesiology services.
Oconee sought proposals for the award of an exclusive agreement to provide staff and anesthesiology services.Â  Both Upstate and McMillan submitted proposals providing four physicians and six staff nurses to perform services at Oconee.Â  However, at the time of the proposal, only two of Upstateâ€™s anesthesiologists and four of the nurses were available to start immediately at Oconee.Â  In contrast, all of McMillanâ€™s personnel were available to start immediately.
Prior to the board at Oconee awarding an exclusive contract, several communications about the new exclusive contract took place between board members and officers at Oconee.Â  Eventually the board awarded the contract to Upstate.Â  McMillan was informed that his privileges at Oconee would end before January of 2002.
As a result of the actions of Oconee and Upstate, McMillan filed suit alleging civil conspiracy, breach of contract, violations of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act, breach of fiduciary duty, tortious interference with existing contractual relations, tortious interference with prospective contractual relations, denial of due process, wrongful taking, and inverse condemnation.Â  In addition, McMillan sought injunctive relief.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of Oconee and Upstate as to the claims for breach of fiduciary duty, tortious interference with existing contractual relation, tortious interference with prospective contractual relations, denial of due process, wrongful taking, and inverse condemnation.Â  Further, the trial court granted Oconee and Upstateâ€™s directed verdict motions for the claims for breach of contract and violations of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act.Â  The parties went to trial on the issues of injunctive relief and civil conspiracy.Â  McMillan claimed that Oconee and Upstate conspired to oust him from his privileges at Oconee.
The jury returned a verdict in favor of McMillan for $1,275,000 against Oconee only.Â  As a result, McMillan made a motion to conform the pleadings to the evidence to allege civil conspiracy against Oconee.Â  Oconee filed post trial motions including a motion to reduce the verdict and a motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict.Â  The trial court granted the motion to reduce the verdict and the verdict was reduced to $300,000 pursuant to the charitable immunity statute.Â  The trial court denied the motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict.Â  In addition, the trial court granted permanent injunctive relief in favor of McMillan allowing him to perform certain limited services at Oconee.Â  However, the trial court granted Oconeeâ€™s application for supersedeas of the injunctive relief pending appeal.
Both parties appealed.Â  As a result, the following issues are before the Court for review:

  
    
      
        I.  
         Did the trial court err in denying Oconeeâ€™s motions for directed verdict and judgment notwithstanding the verdict as to the civil conspiracy claims?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        II. 
         Did the trial court err in reducing the amount of the judgment?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        III.   
         Are the charitable immunity liability limits inapplicable to a claim for civil conspiracy, and as a result, is Oconee not entitled to the statutory protection therein?Â 
      
      
        
         
      
      
        IV. 
         Do the statutory caps applicable to charitable organizations violate equal protection?Â 
      
      
        
         
      
      
        V.
         Did the trial court err in granting McMillan injunctive relief?
      
    
  

Law / Analysis
I.                 
Post Trial Motions 
Oconee argues that the trial court erred in denying its motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict as to the civil conspiracy claim.Â  We agree.
In ruling on motions for directed verdict and JNOV, the trial court is required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motions.Â  Strange v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways and Pub. Transp., 314 S.C. 427, 429-30, 445 S.E.2d 439, 440 (1994).Â  The motions should be denied where either the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.Â  Id.Â  The trial court can only be reversed by this Court when there is no evidence to support the ruling below.Â  Id.Â  
An action for civil conspiracy is an action at law, and the trial courtâ€™s findings will be upheld on appeal unless they are without evidentiary support.Â  Gynecology Clinic, Inc. v. Cloer, 334 S.C. 555, 556, 514 S.E.2d 592, 592-93 (1999).Â  A civil conspiracy is a combination of two or more persons joining for the purpose of injuring and causing special damage to the plaintiff.Â  Lawson v. S.C. Dept. of Corrections, 340 S.C. 346, 352, 532 S.E.2d 289, 261 (2000).Â  Civil conspiracy involves acts that are by their very nature covert and clandestine and usually not susceptible of proof by direct evidence.Â  Robertson v. First Union Natâ€™l Bank, 350 S.C. 339, 349, 565 S.E.2d 309, 314 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  However, a civil conspiracy cannot exist when the alleged acts arise in the context of a principal-agent relationship because by virtue of the relationship such acts do not involve separate entities.Â  Perk v. Vector Resources Group, LTD, 485 S.E.2d 140, 144 (Va. 1997).
While this Court has not addressed the issue directly, this Court has held that agents for a corporation acting in the scope of their duties cannot conspire with the corporation absent the guilty knowledge of a third party.Â  Goble v. Am. Ry. Express Co., et. al., 124 S.C. 19, __, 115 S.E. 900, __ (1923).Â  In support of our Courtâ€™s prior opinion, we believe that it is well settled that a corporation cannot conspire with itself.Â  See 16 Am. Jur. 2d Conspiracy Â§56 (2005) (stating that a corporation cannot be a party to a conspiracy consisting of the corporation and the persons engaged in the management, direction, and control of the corporate affairs, where the individuals are acting only for the corporation and not for any personal purpose of their own). Â Â 
In the present case, the jury returned a verdict against Oconee for civil conspiracy.Â  McMillan then made a motion to conform the pleadings to the evidence to allege an Oconee only conspiracy.Â  As a result, McMillan has failed to allege or prove a conspiracy.Â  A civil conspiracy cannot be found to exist when the acts alleged are those of employees or directors, in their official capacity, conspiring with the corporation.Â  As a result, we hold that no conspiracy can exist if the conduct challenged is a single act by a single corporation acting exclusively through its own directors, officers, and employees, each acting within the scope of his employment.
Therefore, we reverse the denial of the motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict.
II.              
Reduction of the Judgment 
McMillan argues that the trial court erred in reducing the judgment.Â  Because we find that no conspiracy took place and a judgment against Oconee was improper, we do not address the issue of whether the judgment was properly reduced.
III.          
Applicability of Charitable Immunity Provisions 
McMillan argues that the charitable immunity provisions are inapplicable to a claim for civil conspiracy, and as a result, damages may not be capped.Â  Because we hold that no civil conspiracy took place, the issue of the applicability of the charitable immunity statute is moot.
IV.          
Constitutionality of Charitable Immunity Provisions 
McMillan argues that the statutory caps for judgments against charitable organizations violate the equal protection clause of the Constitution.Â  As a result of our holding that no civil conspiracy existed, we do not address this issue.
V.              
Injunctive relief 
Oconee argues that the trial court erred in granting McMillan injunctive relief.Â  We agree.Â  Because McMillan failed to prove a civil conspiracy, the trial judge erred in granting injunctive relief.
Conclusion
Based on the above reasoning, we reverse the trial court.Â  McMillan did not properly allege an action for civil conspiracy.Â  As a result, the trial court erred in denying Oconeeâ€™s motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict.
MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT, and PLEICONES, J.J., concur.
